North Dakota Top 10 Attractions

North Dakota is one of the top destinations in the United States for those with an interest in nature or wildlife, but it also houses zoos, museums, and theaters to provide well-rounded entertainment options for all. Visitors travel to North Dakota for hunting and fishing in a tranquil state, but you can also go for a walk along a river, enjoy the friendliness along the border with Canada, or go out for a night on the town. Agritourism thrives in North Dakota, as do casinos and with the choice of cities or countryside locations, you can find the type of attractions that appeal to you. Lets explore the top 10 attractions in North Dakota.

Best Places to Visit in North Dakota

Table of Contents
  1. Theodore Roosevelt National Park
  2. Fort Mandan Overlook State Historic Site
  3. Maah Daah Hey Trail
  4. North Dakota Heritage Center
  5. Chateau de Mores State Historic Site
  6. National Buffalo Museum
  7. International Peace Garden
  8. Fargo Theatre
  9. Dakota Zoo
  10. Fort Abraham Lincoln State Park

1: Theodore Roosevelt National Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Matt Zimmerman
  • Rate attraction:
  • 190
    59
  • View Map
Comprised of three separate wildlife areas, this national park is named for President Theodore Roosevelt, a noted naturalist and outdoorsman. His Elkhorn ranch, the second of his ranches that he purchased after falling in love with North Dakota on a buffalo hunt, gives name to the Elkhorn Ranch Unit of the park. The main attraction here, besides the sparse and empty beauty of the badlands, is the wildlife. Roosevelt's beloved buffalo can be found here, as well as various types of deer, elk, wild horses, sheep and prairie dogs.

Address: Medora, ND 58645

Website: www.nps.gov

Also Read: What to Pack When Going to a National Park

2: Fort Mandan Overlook State Historic Site

  • Rate attraction:
  • 120
    18
  • View Map
In the winter of 1804, the famed explorers Lewis and Clark built the fort over which this overlook presides. It was here that they met their equally famed Native guide, Sacagawea. Because the fort itself was ultimately swallowed by the nearby river, most of what is known about the fort's history was extrapolated based on found artifacts like arrowheads, pottery, and tools made from animal bones. Today visitors can enjoy an extensive and interactive exhibit detailing the area's history, as well as its current activities and conditions

Address: 8th St SW, Washburn, ND 58577

Website: www.fortmandan.com

3: Maah Daah Hey Trail

  • Rate attraction:
  • 88
    27
  • View Map
This 96-mile trail connects the North and South Units of the Theodore Roosevelt National Park, allowing hikers and horseback riders to get an intimate look at this beautiful and desolate area. The trail is marked by the Maah Daah Hey symbol of a turtle, signifying patience and determination, two necessary components to hiking the trail in its entirety. Overnight campsites with potable water and fire rings exist for thru-hikers, although campers are advised to be aware of the surrounding wildlife.

Address: Medora, ND 58645

Website: www.mdhta.com

4: North Dakota Heritage Center

Photo Courtesy: State Historical Society of North Dakota
  • Rate attraction:
  • 95
    14
  • View Map
This fascinating museum details the history of North Dakota going all the way back to the age of the dinosaurs. Visitors can explore exhibits featuring indigenous people and the artifacts that they left behind. But the past is not the only thing on display. Exhibits with their sights trained on the future include a prototype of a Mars space suit and the possibilities afforded by industry and energy. In every exhibit, the star of the show is North Dakota, whether during its prehistory or its modern iteration as an agricultural powerhouse.

Address: 612 E Boulevard Ave, Bismarck, ND 58501

Website: www.history.nd.gov

Also Read: Top 5 Tourist Attractions in Bismarck, North Dakota

5: Chateau de Mores State Historic Site

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/Chateau De Mores State Historic Site
  • Rate attraction:
  • 79
    17
  • View Map
Named after the Marquis de Mores who purchased this estate and lived here beginning in 1893, this historical site preserves his life and daily tasks as they existed at the time. The Chateau itself was the summer home of the de Mores family, and still displays some original family artifacts. Nearby, the former packing plant where de Mores would slaughter and process beef is now only recognizable by the lone clay chimney that remains. Stagecoach tours run from here to nearby Deadwood, and there is even an undercurrent of intrigue as visitors can observe a dramatic re-enactment of the Marquis de Mores being charged with murder.

Address: 3426 Chateau Rd, Medora, ND 58645

Website: www.history.nd.gov

6: National Buffalo Museum

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/National Buffalo Museum
  • Rate attraction:
  • 78
    16
  • View Map
Once upon a time, buffalo roamed the plains of the United States in such numbers that the land would appear black all the way to the horizon. These days, the land has been tamed and the roaming buffalo herds are a mere fraction of their former numbers. The National Buffalo Museum seeks to preserve the heritage and history of this animal that was such a hallowed part of life on these plains. In addition to educational exhibitions, a live buffalo herd is kept here, which includes the famous albino buffalo known as White Cloud.

Address: 500 17th St SE, Jamestown, ND 58401

Website: www.buffalomuseum.com

7: International Peace Garden

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Kurt Haubrich
  • Rate attraction:
  • 66
    7
  • View Map
This garden lies on the border between the United States and Canada, and was constructed in 1932 as a monument to the peaceful relations enjoyed between the two nations. As it is a garden, over 150,000 flowers are planted every year. Four concrete towers stand, two in each country, with a chapel at the base for quiet reflection. The park also features fountains, chimes, and parts of the World Trade Center from the September 11, 2001 World Trade Center attacks.

Address: 10939 US-281, Dunseith, ND 58329

Website: www.peacegarden.com

8: Fargo Theatre

Photo Courtesy: fargotheatre.org
  • Rate attraction:
  • 53
    12
  • View Map
The marquee that marks the Fargo Theatre reveals its origins as a vaudeville and cinema theatre built in 1926. In addition to the high caliber films for which it is known, it also occasionally features live performances. Because of its long and successful history of being a downtown destination since the Jazz Age, it has been officially added to the National Register of Historic Places, making it a necessary stop for history buffs as well as film enthusiasts.

Address: 314 Broadway N, Fargo, ND 58102

Website: www.fargotheatre.org

9: Dakota Zoo

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Josh Grenier
  • Rate attraction:
  • 76
    6
  • View Map
This zoo's origins are humble, beginning with a married couple's domesticated animals. What began as a boarding house for cats, dogs, and horses soon grew, as concerned citizens would leave strays and feral animals to the couple for safekeeping. Eventually a petition to open a community zoo was signed, and the Dakota Zoo began. It now houses a variety of exotic animals including camels and snow leopards, as well as native fauna like pronghorns and coyotes.

Address: 602 Riverside Park Rd, Bismarck, ND 58504

Website: www.dakotazoo.org

Also Read: Top 5 Tourist Attractions in Bismarck, North Dakota

10: Fort Abraham Lincoln State Park

  • Rate attraction:
  • 52
    13
  • View Map
Originally inhabited by the Mandan native tribe in 1575, this area became a military post in the 19th century. Famed and ultimately ill fated U.S. lieutenant colonel George Custer served here before his demise during the Battle of Little Bighorn. The On-A-Slant Indian Village, an earthlodge compound inhabited by the Mandans, has been partially recreated for visitors. The Custer House has been rebuilt for the sake of preserving history, and the Five Nations art house deals in works created by Native peoples.

Address: 4480 Fort Lincoln Rd, Mandan, ND 58554

Website: www.parkrec.nd.gov

Also Read: 10 Best State Parks in the United States

Wisconsin Top 20 Attractions

Wisconsin is in the heart of the Midwest, with access to Lake Michigan and a diverse geography.

Throughout the entire state, there are plenty of attractions you can visit, offering something for everyone whether you prefer nightlife, outdoors, museums, water sports, festivals, or the dairy that the state is famous for.

Below rundown on top 20 attractions in Wisconsin cover all the major sights ranging from museums for those who want to learn about a particular subject, sports attractions, to opportunities for spending some time outdoors.

Best Places to Visit in Wisconsin

Table of Contents
  1. Waterparks, Wisconsin Dells
  2. Harley-Davidson Museum, Milwaukee
  3. Door County
  4. Olbrich Botanical Gardens, Madison
  5. The Green Bay Packers: Lambeau Field And The Walk Of Legends
  6. Circus World Museum, Baraboo
  7. Geneva Lake Shore Path, Lake Geneva
  8. Wisconsin State Capitol
  9. EAA AirVenture Show And Museum, Oshkosh
  10. Cave of the Mounds, Blue Mounds
  11. Taliesin Preservation
  12. House on the Rock
  13. Devil’s Lake State Park
  14. National Railroad Museum
  15. Mitchell Park Horticultural Conservatory
  16. Pattison State Park
  17. Lake Minocqua
  18. Wisconsin Great River Road
  19. Bay Beach Amusement Park
  20. Wisconsin Ice Age Trail

1: Waterparks, Wisconsin Dells

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/mtolympuspark
  • Rate attraction:
  • 181
    25
  • View Map

Wisconsin Dells is known as the best spot in the state for fun at waterparks, and it is actually the "Waterpark Capital of the World."

This is where the very first indoor water park was pioneered and houses the biggest concentration worldwide of indoor and outdoor waterparks.

This means that you can look at just indoor waterparks or just outdoor ones and still have dozens of choices. Many of these parks have lodging right on site.

This is also where you'll find Noah's Ark Waterpark, the largest outdoor one in the country.

Address: 701 Superior St, Wisconsin Dells, Wisconsin 53965

Accomodation: Where to stay in Wisconsin Dells

Also Read: Top 5 Water & Amusement Parks in Wisconsin Dells

2: Harley-Davidson Museum, Milwaukee

  • Rate attraction:
  • 92
    20
  • View Map

Motorcycle enthusiasts will have a grand time exploring this museum that features all the best bikes in the world. Visit their Design Lab to see what goes on behind the scenes of making the world's finest bikes.

Go to the Experience Gallery where you can actually sit on the bikes and feel what it is like to ride a Harley. The museum consists of about 450 artifacts and motorcycles, including the oldest Harley-Davidson motorcycle that is known, Serial Number One.

Even the building itself is gorgeous as Pentagram Architects designed it. If you don't want to pay for museum entry, but want to take advantage of the space, get a meal at the restaurant, Motor.

Address: 400 W Canal St, Milwaukee, WI 53201

Accomodation: Where to stay in Milwaukee

Website: www.harley-davidson.com

Also Read: Top 10 Tourist Attractions in Milwaukee, Wisconsin

3: Door County

  • Rate attraction:
  • 101
    44
  • View Map

Door County is perfect for outdoor recreation as well as the performing arts. There are 11 lighthouses, 300 miles of shoreline, and 5 state parks to enjoy.

You can stay in any type of accommodation, including camping, bed and breakfasts, or even historic inns. You can go fruit picking, with apples or cherries depending on the season.

There are also numerous concerts, outdoor theater performances, and outdoor sports to enjoy, such as hiking, birding, paddling, and more.

Address: 1015 Green Bay Rd, Sturgeon Bay, Wisconsin 54235

Accomodation: Where to stay in Door County

Website: www.doorcounty.com

4: Olbrich Botanical Gardens, Madison

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/kfcasper
  • Rate attraction:
  • 84
    21
  • View Map

The Olbrich Botanical Gardens cover 16 acres of gorgeous gardens, including the only Thai Pavilion within the continental US as well as the only one of its kind surrounded by garden outside of Thailand.

There is also a rose garden, herb garden, Sunken Garden, and Perennial Garden. While at this attraction, visit the Bolz Conservatory, which is a 50-foot-high pyramid with a rushing waterfall, blooming orchids, free-flying birds, and tropical plants.

You can look at carnivorous plants as well as those responsible for growing your favorite foods like vanilla, coffee, and bananas.

Address: 3330 Atwood Ave, Madison, WI 53704

Accomodation: Where to stay in Madison

Website: www.olbrich.org

Also Read: Madison, Wisconsin Top 10 Attractions

5: The Green Bay Packers: Lambeau Field And The Walk Of Legends

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Mike Morbeck
  • Rate attraction:
  • 105
    18
  • View Map

The Green Bay Packers are very important the majority of Wisconsites and most visitors take advantage of their vacation to learn more.

Lambeau Field is where the Packers play, and you can attend events here, watch a game, or visit the Atrium. There you will find the Packers Pro Shop as well as the Hall of Fame, which commemorates top players throughout the years.

You can also go on a guided Stadium Tour to learn more. Exit Lambeau Field and go to the public art walkway just to the east of the building to enjoy the Walk of Legends.

This is a collection of 24 statues that honor legendary eras of the Packers as well as the legends that made them great.

Address: 1265 Lombardi Ave, Green Bay, WI 54304

Accomodation: Where to stay in Green Bay

6: Circus World Museum, Baraboo

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Amy Meredith
  • Rate attraction:
  • 51
    10
  • View Map

The Circus World Museum first opened in 1954 and today it is constantly expanding with new exhibits, including those that feature restored original Ringling Brothers structures, electronic media, and live programs.

The museum started with six old wagons from the circus and under an acre, but today there are 30 permanent structures over 64 acres of land, as well as winter quarters and the train shed complex.

One of the high-points of the museum is the Siemor Bros. Miniature Circus which took Mel and Lottie Romels 40 years to finish and can now be found in the Spectacle Room.

Address: 550 Water St, Baraboo, WI 53913

Accomodation: Where to stay in Baraboo

Website: www.circusworldbaraboo.org

7: Geneva Lake Shore Path, Lake Geneva

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/atramos
  • Rate attraction:
  • 58
    6
  • View Map

For a relaxing day in Wisconsin, head to Lake Geneva and take a stroll along the Geneva Lake Shore Path.

This covers 21 miles and gives you the unique opportunity to walk through the backyard of numerous mansions which are at least a century old.

The earliest settlers of the area decided that the 20 feet closest to the shoreline would be public domain and this has continued today, giving you gorgeous views of the shoreline, gorgeous homes, and exquisite landscaping.

Address: Lake Geneva, WI 53147

Accomodation: Where to stay in Lake Geneva

Website: www.lakegenevawi.com

8: Wisconsin State Capitol

Photo Courtesy: wikimedia/Vkoulampet
  • Rate attraction:
  • 45
    13
  • View Map

The Wisconsin State Capitol building can be found in the Madison area and is home to a number of government departments and offices. The structure dates back to 1917 and is now the tallest building in the Madison area.

Wisconsin State Capitol is part of what has become known as Capitol Square, which is made up of a range of other businesses including shops and eateries amongst others.

You can enjoy exploring the building itself by booking a guided tour, which will enable you to take in the fascinating architecture as well as the stunning monuments, elaborate décor, and exhibitions.

Address: 2 E Main St, Madison, WI 53703

Website: tours.wisconsin.gov

Also Read: Madison, Wisconsin Top 10 Attractions

9: EAA AirVenture Show And Museum, Oshkosh

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/D. Miller
  • Rate attraction:
  • 35
    11
  • View Map

The museum's collection of 20,000 historic artifacts dates way back to 1962. With their extensive displays of aircrafts as well as educational tours that will give you everything that you need to know about flying, you are surely going to have a fantastic time with your entire family.

The AirVenture show takes place every summer and lasts a full week. It includes exhibits, air shows, the chance to explore aircrafts, and even theater.

Address: 3000 Poberezny Rd Oshkosh, WI 54902

Accomodation: Where to stay in Oshkosh

Website: www.airventuremuseum.org

Also Read: Top 10 Space and Aviation Museums in the USA

10: Cave of the Mounds, Blue Mounds

  • Rate attraction:
  • 52
    17
  • View Map

Cave of the Mounds National Landmark was discovered in 1939 and is now the premier cave within the upper Midwest.

You can go on guided tours of the cave that show you the colorful crystals formed along the paved walkways. The cave tour is perfect for the entire family and shows you columns, stalagmites, stalactites, and more.

There is also a butterfly garden, fossil dig, gemstone mine, biking and biking trails, and a gift shop.

Address: 2975 Cave of the Mounds Rd Blue Mounds, WI 53517

Accomodation: Where to stay in Blue Mounds

Website: www.caveofthemounds.com

11: Taliesin Preservation

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/K Tao
  • Rate attraction:
  • 3
    0
  • View Map

Located near Spring Green, the Taliesin Preservation is a popular tourist destination for learning more about Frank Lloyd Wright.

The late Frank Lloyd Wright was a famous, award-winning architect, born in Wisconsin. His architecture is seen all around the world, with some of the most impressive creations housed on the Taliesin Preservation.

The preservation was Wright’s residence and private studio – the grounds also includes other buildings designed by him.

Taliesin Preservation is a place to learn about Wright’s life, legacy, and inspiration behind some of his most iconic buildings. Visitors can walk the grounds, immersing into the beautiful design of the house merging perfectly with nature.

The preservation includes a visitor center, providing more information about the grounds. Visitors can also begin their guided tours at the center – expert guides walk with you around the house and other buildings while telling stories about Wright.

Address: 5607 County Road C, Spring Green, WI 53588

Accomodation: Where to stay in Spring Green

Website: www.taliesinpreservation.org

12: House on the Rock

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Chris Lott
  • Rate attraction:
  • 3
    0
  • View Map

A visit to the House on the Rock will be one of the unique experiences you could imagine in Wisconsin. The house is an architectural complex and entertainment site designed by Alex Jordan Jr., a famous architect. His work on the house expanded to include an entire complex of fun, must-see attractions for visitors.

The primary House on the Rock was built in 1959 and opened to the public the following year. The house is only part of the attraction, as additional buildings were constructed in later years.

Explore the distinct rooms of the house, which showcase antiques and collectibles. The infinity room is one of the most popular rooms, designed as an illusion to go on forever.

The site also includes The Streets of Yesterday, a recreation of an American town, and the Music of Yesterday, an exhibit designed with automated musical instruments.

Address: 5754 WI-23, Spring Green, WI 53588

Website: www.thehouseontherock.com

13: Devil’s Lake State Park

Photo Courtesy: Celley/USFWS
  • Rate attraction:
  • 4
    0
  • View Map

Devil’s Lake State Park is Wisconsin’s largest state park, covering over 9,000 acres of the Baraboo Range. It’s the most visited park in the state with more than three million visitors every year, arriving for recreational activities, exploring the wildlife, or sightseeing.

Devil’s Lake State Park was established in 1911, becoming a popular destination thanks to its proximity to Madison.

The park's highlight is Devil's Lake – visitors can enjoy lots of outdoor recreation at the lake, including kayaking, fishing, hiking, and climbing. The lake is a well-known research site as it was formed from glacier activity in the park.

The beautiful park contains many other sights worth checking out during a visit. It has many unique quartzite rock formations such as Balanced Rock, or you can visit the winding Effigy Mounds.

Devil's Lake State Park has many visitor facilities, including a visitor center and over 400 campgrounds permitting overnight stays.

Address: S5975 Park Rd, Baraboo, WI 53913

Website: dnr.wi.gov

14: National Railroad Museum

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Andrew Phelps
  • Rate attraction:
  • 4
    0
  • View Map

Railroad enthusiasts will have the time of their lives at the National Railroad Museum, one of the first railroad museums established in the country. The museum is dedicated to all things railroad for preserving more than 100 years of history.

National Railroad Museum is located in the Greater Green Bay area. The museum experience includes both indoor and outdoor exhibits.

The indoor exhibitions feature various railroad artifacts, photos, and other collected archives. Check out the indoor train yard to climb inside some of the historical locomotives. The outdoor exhibit features a wide range of trains, from steam-powered to electric-powered trains.

The historical trains are preserved to showcase their original appearance and condition. There are several noteworthy trains such as presidential trains and trains set for use during the World Wars.

The museum hosts train rides during special events.

During your visit, climb to the top of the observation tower for scenic views of Green Bay and the Fox River.

Address: 2285 S Broadway, Green Bay, WI 54304

Website: www.nationalrrmuseum.org

15: Mitchell Park Horticultural Conservatory

Photo Courtesy: Wikimedia Commons/Sulfur
  • Rate attraction:
  • 4
    0
  • View Map

Mitchell Park is home to the Mitchell Park Horticultural Conservatory, a collection of three botanical gardens housed in large domes – locals refer to the attraction simply at ‘The Domes.’ The conservatory showcases over 1000 beautiful plant species from around the world.

Mitchell Park Horticultural Conservatory is divided into three domes: Show Dome, Tropical Dome, and Arid Dome. Each of the domes presents a particular climate zone and ecosystem for housing plants native to the conditions.

Explore the Tropical Dome to see close to 1000 different plants native to tropical climates. Many of the plants featured in the dome are fruit-bearing trees such as cacao and bananas.

The Arid Dome has plants from various regions of the world, including across the Americas and Africa. The plants are endemic to desert climate, with the temperature inside the dome regulated for sustainability.

The Show Dome features seasonal shows and exhibits, changing four times every year. It also hosts special shows for the holidays.

Address: 524 S Layton Blvd, Milwaukee, WI 53215

Website: county.milwaukee.gov

16: Pattison State Park

  • Rate attraction:
  • 4
    0
  • View Map

Pattison State Park is one of the top state park attractions in Wisconsin. It’s located in the northern region off the coast of Lake Superior. It’s a great destination all year round with fun outdoor activities for any time you visit.

The Big Manitou Falls is one of the biggest attractions to the state park – it’s Wisconsin’s highest waterfall. The park also includes Little Manitou Falls, another point of interest for visitors.

Outdoor recreation is very popular at Pattison State Park. Some of the favorite activities include hiking, swimming, and camping. Hiking trails extend for miles throughout the park. Visitors can also take guided walking tours to learn more about the flora and sightsee wildlife during the trek.

There are nearly 60 family-friendly campsites, several with working electricity and updated facilities.

Visit the park’s nature center to learn more about the park’s natural history and its cultural significance.

Address: 6294 WI-35, Superior, WI 54880

Accomodation: Where to stay in Superior

Website: dnr.wi.gov

17: Lake Minocqua

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Sara
  • Rate attraction:
  • 4
    0
  • View Map

Wisconsin has several popular lake destinations, especially in the Lakeland region in the north. One of the premier lakes in the area is Lake Minocqua. Although surrounded by many other lakes, it’s one of the must-visit lakes for everybody visiting.

Lake Minocqua is a large, beautiful lake providing magnificent scenery while enjoying lake activities. People visit the lake at any time of the year since there are always things to do. During the summertime, some of the favorite lake activities include boating, water skiing, and swimming. Fishing is also permitted at the lake. During the wintertime, many people snowmobile on the lake.

Lake Minocqua is the perfect vacation spot – the lake is developed for tourism with lots of resorts and lake houses set up around it. Stay at one of the nearby accommodations to enjoy the beautiful sunsets and sunrises over the lake.

Address: Oneida County, WI

Website: dnr.wi.gov

18: Wisconsin Great River Road

Photo Courtesy: Travel Wisconsin
  • Rate attraction:
  • 3
    0
  • View Map

The famous Great River Road passes through the Western border of Wisconsin on a journey that extends for over 2,000-miles along the Mississippi River. The road runs north to south from Minnesota to Louisiana – each state promotes its local section as a tourist attraction.

Wisconsin Great River Road predominantly consists of WIS 35 – it's included as part of a National Scenic Byway where visitors will have fantastic scenery along the drive. The drive is famous when traveling to add a bit of fun to the road trip – you can go through multiple states or just enjoy Wisconsin's section of the attraction.

Some of the sights along the road include views of the Mississippi River, dams, boats, and more. The road shoulders are the perfect place to stop and enjoy the view from designated overlooks. There are also plenty of themed restaurants to visit along the way.

Address: Great River Rd, WI

Website: www.wigrr.com

19: Bay Beach Amusement Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Jeremy Thompson
  • Rate attraction:
  • 5
    0
  • View Map

Get ready for some old fashion family fun when you visit the Bay Beach Amusement Park. The amusement park is in Green Bay, open seasonally from May to September.

For over a century, families have visited the park to enjoy lots of rides and attractions since it first opened in 1892. The park is unique compared to other amusement parks because it maintains its original prices – ride tickets cost only a quarter.

Bay Beach Amusement Park has something to do for everyone. There are 23 rides, a vintage wooden roller coaster, food stations, bumper cars, and a Ferris Wheel. Take a ride on the Zippin Pippin roller coaster for a thrill ride or hop on the Ferris Wheel for beautiful views overlooking Lake Michigan. The park includes kid’s rides.

Visit the park’s pavilion for a variety of events and performances during the open season.

Address: 1313 Bay Beach Rd, Green Bay, WI 54302

Accomodation: Where to stay in Green Bay

Website: www.greenbaywi.gov

20: Wisconsin Ice Age Trail

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Joshua Mayer
  • Rate attraction:
  • 4
    0
  • View Map

Wisconsin Ice Age Trail is the most famous National Scenic Trail in the state – the major trail extends for 1,200-miles across Wisconsin, with approximately half of it already developed. It’s mainly used for hiking and sightseeing, offering an excellent opportunity to see the state’s diverse landscape. 

Wisconsin Ice Age Trail has trailheads at Potawatomi State Park and Interstate State Park. The trail winds throughout the state passing through a variety of landscapes, including the Chequamegon-Nicolet National Forest, Lookout Mountain, and other landscape features left behind by glacial activity.

Visit a nearby section of the trail as an excellent destination for outdoor recreation. It's a year-round destination where you can enjoy hiking in the Summer and snowshoe trekking in the winter. Most visitors enjoy regional sections of the trail, although long-distance hikes are permitted. You can find designated camping sites on the trail.

Address: Eagle, WI 53119

Accomodation: Where to stay in Eagle

Website: www.iceagetrail.org

Connecticut Top 10 Attractions

Just when you thought you have traveled enough to explore the best of what America can offer, there are always new and more exciting attractions that open in different parts of the country. One of the best places to visit is the elegant state of Connecticut.

Here you will surely find something enjoyable to do no matter how old you are or what your interests are. If you are planning on making Connecticut your next travel destination, here are some of the top 10 attractions that you should not miss.

Best Places to Visit in Connecticut

Table of Contents
  1. Mystic Seaport
  2. Historic Ship Nautilus & Submarine Force Museum
  3. Lake Compounce Amusement Park
  4. Beardsley Zoo
  5. Hammonasset Beach State Park
  6. Mystic Aquarium & Institute for Exploration
  7. Dinosaur State Park and Arboretum
  8. Gillette Castle State Park
  9. The Mark Twain House & Museum
  10. Yale University Art Gallery

1: Mystic Seaport

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Ken Mist
  • Rate attraction:
  • 100
    54
  • View Map

As the largest maritime museum in the United States, the Mystic Seaport is an essential Connecticut stop! Its full name is actually the Mystic Seaport: The Museum of America and the Sea in Mystic.

It features a wide variety of water vessels from many different eras of maritime adventure. It is specifically popular for its extensive 19th century recreation of a seafaring village. However, that’s just one of the many incredible exhibits. There is so much to see at Mystic Seaport!

You can climb aboard historic vessels, take a cruise down the Mystic River aboard a wooden coal-fired steamboat, and explore highly interactive displays and exhibits that include a working preservation shipyard in action.

General admission tickets vary by age. For adults, the price is $28.95. Seniors (65+) are $26.95, youths (13-17) are $24.95, children (3-12) are $18.95, and anyone younger than 2 is free. The museum is open daily from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. excluding national holidays.

There is also free parking just across the street, and a magnificent aquarium just next door. If you’re interested in the aquarium, look into some of the bundle passes like the Mystic Pass Card so that you can really see it all in Mystic, Connecticut.

Address: 75 Greenmanville Ave, Mystic, CT 06355

Website: www.mysticseaport.org

2: Historic Ship Nautilus & Submarine Force Museum

Photo Courtesy: Wikimedia/Z22
  • Rate attraction:
  • 41
    15
  • View Map

Located on the Thames River in Groton, Connecticut, the Submarine Force Museum houses the world's finest collection of submarine artifacts. It is operated by the United States Navy and is the main source of documents, photographs and artifacts related to the U.S Submarine Force.

Go onboard the Nautilus to give you a thrilling first-hand experience of being a submariner. Watch movies of the USS Nautilus and explore the Medal of Honor gallery to learn more about the brave heroes of the US Marines.

Address: 1 Crystal Lake Rd, Groton, CT 06340

Website: www.ussnautilus.org

3: Lake Compounce Amusement Park

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/Lake Compounce
  • Rate attraction:
  • 72
    7
  • View Map

Lake Compounce is known as the oldest and longest operating amusement park in America. In fact, it has been operating for 156 years now. Over the recent years the park has invested millions of dollars to continue making it the best place to visit in Connecticut.

Here you can enjoy breathtaking rides like the Boulder Dash, Down Time, the Enterprise and the Pirate Ship among others. You can also enjoy their water rides, kiddie and family rides, as well as some highly entertaining musical shows.

Address: 186 Enterprise Dr, Bristol, CT 06010

Website: www.lakecompounce.com

4: Beardsley Zoo

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/Beardsley Zoo
  • Rate attraction:
  • 61
    13
  • View Map

Walk amongst the wildlife in Connecticut’s famed Beardsley Zoo. Currently, it is the only AZA-accredited Connecticut zoo. It is also an extensive testament to all things nature!

It has several exhibits, shows, attractions--- and even one of the state’s only carousels. There is so much to explore from reserves, to games, to some good ole fashioned zoo food that makes the trip a family favorite.

Animals here are well protected and cared for, and the experience is truly something you’ll never forget. Watch a tiger prowl, a giraffe feed, or a gorilla interact with friends all within one incredible zoo.

Rates vary by age, but generally adult tickets are $15. The zoo is open from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. everyday. However, if you want to make the most out of your trip, it is recommended you get started early.

Most animals are early risers, and you’ll be able to see a lot more if you give yourself an extra hour or so in the park. The Beardsley Zoo is large enough that you will need the full day to embrace all of its wonderful attractions.

Address: 1875 Noble Ave, Bridgeport, CT 06610

Website: www.beardsleyzoo.org

5: Hammonasset Beach State Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Chris Amelung
  • Rate attraction:
  • 47
    12
  • View Map

Spend the day soaking in the sunshine! Hammonasset Beach State Park is two long, golden miles of prime beachfront property. It is one of the most popular attractions as visitors can play in the waves, lay out a nice towel, or play a couple of fun beach games.

This is one of the best spots in the state to go for a little serenity. There are parts where the crowds congregate, and sections entirely undisturbed. It’s all about finding what suits you, and then enjoying your slice of paradise.

As a state park, this beach is well-maintained by the state. It also operates on set hours and includes a few fees. The park is open every day from 8 a.m. to sunset, with the campground open (mid-May to Labor Day) and only monitored after sunset.

To park by Hammonasset Beach State Park you must pay the $13.83 fee on weekends, and $9.57 on weekdays for residents. Any visitors pay $23.40 on weekends, and $15.95. But a stay here is well worth any cost as you will remember this sun kissed dream for many months to come.

Address: 1288 Boston Post Rd, Madison, CT 06443

Website: www.ct.gov

6: Mystic Aquarium & Institute for Exploration

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Eric Savage
  • Rate attraction:
  • 44
    9
  • View Map

Explore the marine world right here at the Mystic Aquarium. Founded in 1973 to serve as a living laboratory and as a major public exhibit, this is currently one of the most visited attractions in Connecticut.

Take your children here to touch and feel the reptiles at the Scales and Tails exhibit, visit the Titanic exhibit to journey to new depths of discovery and visit the Nautilus Live Theater to learn more about the underwater world.

Address: 55 Coogan Blvd, Mystic, CT 06355

Website: www.mysticaquarium.org

7: Dinosaur State Park and Arboretum

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Kyle Hartshorn
  • Rate attraction:
  • 32
    13
  • View Map

Have you always been fascinated by dinosaurs? Visit the Dinosaur State Park which is known as one of the country's largest dinosaur track sites. Underneath the park's geodesic dome, you will find an impressive display of Jurassic fossil tracks made over 200 million years ago.

Go on a hike to explore more than 2 miles of nature trails as well as the Dinosaur State Park Arboretum to discover some unique flora and plant families that appeared during the age of the dinosaurs.

Address: 400 West St, Rocky Hill, CT 06067

8: Gillette Castle State Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Joe Mabel
  • Rate attraction:
  • 38
    21
  • View Map

Built in 1914, Connecticut is the proud owner of its very own castle! The Gillette Castle State Park is a beloved staple mark of the state and draws hundreds of tourists to its historic doors.

This is a great site to walk the entire grounds, and really see all that décor and grandeur can do. It is a medieval-style building that was once owned by actor William Gillette. The Gillette Castle is a massive building with some of the most beautiful architecture in all of Connecticut.

Visitors can really see all the influences of the ages in every nook and cranny of this attraction. Be sure to opt for a tour and get a closer look at all that makes this place spectacular!

The Gillette Castle interior tour fees are as follows: $6 for adults, $2 for those aged 6-12, and free for children 5 and under. The park grounds by the castle are open from 8 a.m. to sunset every day. The castle itself is open seven days a week from Memorial Day Weekend through Labor Day.

Tours are available from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. As this is a very popular attraction, it is recommended to visit this site somewhere close to the opening hours. Not only will there be less people, but you’ll have more room to free roam and have all the time needed to truly see it all.

Address: 67 River Rd, East Haddam, CT 06423

Website: www.ct.gov

Also Read: 10 Best State Parks in the United States

9: The Mark Twain House & Museum

Photo Courtesy: Wikimedia/Cliff
  • Rate attraction:
  • 36
    13
  • View Map

Learn about the legacy, the talent and the genius of the man behind the infamous book The Adventures of Tom Sawyer. In 2003, the Mark Twain Museum opened to the public and offered visitors the opportunity to learn, discover, and appreciate Twain's fascinating personal and professional life.

At the Aetna Gallery you will see a permanent exhibition of Twain's life and works. Watch an interesting film documentary on Mark Twain at the Hartford Financial Services Theater then drop by the museum's gift shop for a souvenir or two before heading home.

Address: 351 Farmington Ave, Hartford, CT 06105

Website: www.marktwainhouse.org

Also Read: Top 10 Tourist Attractions in Hartford, Connecticut

10: Yale University Art Gallery

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/boscdanjou
  • Rate attraction:
  • 27
    28
  • View Map

When you pay a visit to the Yale University Art Gallery in Connecticut you can look forward to inspirational exhibits and a wide range of art collections that are designed to fascinate and educate.

You can enjoy taking in both permanent and travelling exhibitions at this gallery and some of the collections include Asian Art, African Art, Modern and Contemporary Art, and photography amongst many others.

The museum is also free to visit so you can enjoy all of these collections and displays at no cost. There are also educational programs available catering for both adults and children.

Address: 1111 Chapel St, New Haven, CT 06510

Website: artgallery.yale.edu

Massachusetts Top 10 Attractions

One of the most fulfilling things that you can do in your life is to explore your own country by making it a point to travel to a new state every now and then. If you are currently deciding on where to go for your next great American adventure, you should try checking out all the attractions that you can enjoy in the exciting state of Massachusetts. Here is our list of the must-see and must-do attractions in Massachusetts.

Best Places to Visit in Massachusetts

Table of Contents
  1. Freedom Trail
  2. Faneuil Hall Marketplace
  3. Norman Rockwell Museum
  4. Cape Cod Beaches
  5. Fenway Park
  6. Nantucket
  7. Tanglewood Concerts
  8. Mayflower II and Plimoth Plantation
  9. Old Sturbridge Village
  10. Salem’s Historic Houses

1: Freedom Trail

  • Rate attraction:
  • 88
    24
  • View Map

Running for four kilometers through the downtown Boston area in Massachusetts, the Freedom Trail takes visitors past a variety of historical locations that have played a vital part in the history of America.

As you make your way along the trail you will be able to take in a range of historical places of interest including churches, graveyards, and historical houses such as the Old South Meeting House.

There are also markers along the way providing information, which enables you to make the most of your experience. This is a great way to visitors to explore and enjoy some of this most historically significant landmarks and places of interest in the area.

Address: Freedom Trail, Boston, MA

Website: www.thefreedomtrail.org

Also Read: Top 10 Tourist Attractions in Boston, Massachusetts

2: Faneuil Hall Marketplace

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/masstravel
  • Rate attraction:
  • 68
    11
  • View Map

Located in downtown Boston, here you will find over 100 nationally recognized retail shops and restaurants that give you the most festive shopping experience you will ever have.

This marketplace is filled with some of the most unique and exquisite architectural treasures that you will never find elsewhere.

If you are looking for a souvenir to bring home to your loved ones, you will surely find one at Faneuil Hall Marketplace.

Address: 4 S Market St, Boston, MA 02109

Website: www.FaneuilHallMarketplace.com

3: Norman Rockwell Museum

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/masstravel
  • Rate attraction:
  • 60
    16
  • View Map

When you visit the Normal Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge, you will be able to enjoy feasting your eyes on the largest collection of Rockwell art on the globe.

This museum is, of course, dedicated to the talented 20th century artist and in addition to displaying his work it also provides access to various artifacts such as photos, documents and even letters from fans.

Not only will you be able to take in the art exhibitions and displays when you visit this popular attractions but you can also look forward to learning more about Norman Rockwell and his life.

Address: 9 MA-183, Stockbridge, MA 01262

Website: www.nrm.org

4: Cape Cod Beaches

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/|vv@ldzen|
  • Rate attraction:
  • 75
    13
  • View Map

There are many things to love about Massachusetts and this includes the wonderful beaches that can be found around the Cape Cod area. These are beaches that are perfect for everything from relaxation and kicking back through to outdoor recreation, fun with the family, and excitement.

Many are known for great surfing opportunities while others boast incredible scenery and landscapes.

Some of the great beaches that you should visit in the Cape Cod area include the family oriented Breakwater Beach, Sandwich Town Beach which is great for scuba diving, Sandy Neck Beach with its great views and wildlife, and the attractive Cahoon Hollow Beach.

Address: Cape Cod, Massachusetts

Also Read: Top 10 Tourist Attractions in Cape Cod and the Islands

5: Fenway Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/masstravel
  • Rate attraction:
  • 79
    8
  • View Map

MLBs oldest ballpark, Fenway Park is home to the popular Boston Red Sox and is located close to Kenmore Square in Boston. For those who are fans of the Red Sox or of sports in general, a tour of this venue is a great option when you visit the area.

You can look forward to a walking tour in the park complete with a knowledgeable guide to help you to make the most of your experience. This will enable you to learn more about the park and its history as well as about the Red Sox.

You can also enjoy seeing some of the unique features of the park up close and personal including the Green Monster and Pesky’s Pole.

Address: 4 Yawkey Way, Boston, MA 02215

Also Read: Top 10 Most Amazing Arenas And Stadiums In America

6: Nantucket

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/masstravel
  • Rate attraction:
  • 40
    11
  • View Map

Charming, idyllic and romantic, Nantucket provides you with the best place to spend quality time with your loved ones.

Here you can enjoy swimming in some of the world's most pristine beaches, go fishing, biking, and hiking, explore museums, and enjoy a slice of the good life.

With all the activities and cozy lodges that Nantucket has to offer, it is no wonder that this is one of the country's most visited vacation spots.

Address: Nantucket, MA

Website: www.nantucket-ma.gov

Also Read: Top 10 Tourist Attractions in Cape Cod and the Islands

7: Tanglewood Concerts

Photo Courtesy: Wikimedia/Titus.jon
  • Rate attraction:
  • 32
    13
  • View Map

Situated in western Massachusetts, Tanglewood is a venue that offers a host of entertainment for those who have a love for music.

Since the 1930s, the venue has been home to the fabulous Boston Symphony Orchestra but there are also three music schools there, which are the Tanglewood Music Center, the Boston University Tanglewood Institute and Days in the Arts.

Tanglewood is therefore able to play host to a range of musical entertainment and concerts to suit all tastes from classical to jazz and popular music.

Address: 297 West St, Lenox, MA 01240

Website: www.bso.org

8: Mayflower II and Plimoth Plantation

Photo Courtesy: Wikimedia/Muns
  • Rate attraction:
  • 45
    9
  • View Map

A replica of the vessel that transported Pilgrims to Plymouth in the 1600s, the Mayflower II provides a fascinating historical experience for visitors. You can enjoy listening to the stories and tales from the costumed characters as well as exploring the vessel itself.

This is just one of the attractions at the Plimoth Plantation, where there are many other historical attractions to look forward to. This includes the Plimoth Grist Mill as well as the fascinating 17th Century English village, which provides an insight into the community that was created by the pilgrims.

With the variety of history exhibits, this is an experience that is as enlightening as it is fascinating.

Address: 137 Warren Ave, Plymouth, MA 02360

Website: www.plimoth.org

9: Old Sturbridge Village

  • Rate attraction:
  • 27
    7
  • View Map

A unique and exciting living history museum, Old Sturbridge Village has become very popular amongst tourists as well as for educational trips. There are over 200 acres to explore here where you can enjoy learning more about life in the area from the 1790s to the 1830s.

You can enjoy taking in the wonderful historic setting and ambiance while soaking up some of the local history of rural New England.

You can really immerse yourself in the past and step back in time when you visit this village and in addition to enjoying the setting you will also find some fascinating exhibits to help you to further enhance your trip. This is a place that really brings history to life making it well worth a visit.

Address: 1 Old Sturbridge Village Rd, Sturbridge, MA 01566

Website: www.osv.org

10: Salem’s Historic Houses

Photo Courtesy: Dreamstime/Martial Genest
  • Rate attraction:
  • 37
    21
  • View Map

Salem in Massachusetts is a place that is well known for its long, rich, fascinating and sometimes dark history. It is also a place filled with historic places of interest including a number of historic houses.

When you visit this area you should make sure that you put at least some of these historic houses on your itinerary, as they will help you to capture the essence of Salem history.

Some of the key historic houses to visit when you come here include the Salem Maritime National Historic Site, the House of the Seven Gables, the Witch House, and the Stephen Phillips Memorial Trust House amongst others.

Address: 193 Derby St, Salem, MA 01970

New York State Top 20 Attractions

When most people think about traveling to New York, their eyes are set on visiting New York City. Although it’s one of the best places to visit in New York State, there are many other destinations that you don’t want to miss out on.

New York State is full of exciting destinations that you’ll have to see to believe. It’s a large state where you’ll find major cities, some of the most picturesque natural scenery, natural landmarks, and much more. Explore all the regions of the state to get a genuine appreciation of all it has to offer.

The New York attractions in the northern region showcase incredible nature for outdoor activities in every season – hiking nature trails to skiing mountain slopes. Other areas gained prominence as vacation getaway destinations for people living in the big city.

Still, New York City remains unmatched when it comes to tourism – it's one of the world's top travel destinations. There are many must-visit attractions in the state ranging from incredible architectural wonders to the largest urban zoo in the United States.

Let’s explore some of the top attractions in New York State that you’ll have to add to your bucket list during your next visit.

Best Places to Visit in New York State

  1. Times Square
  2. Statue of Liberty
  3. Niagara Falls
  4. Metropolitan Museum of Art
  5. Central Park
  6. Hudson Valley
  7. Letchworth State Park

  9. Thousand Islands
  10. Finger Lakes
  11. Watkins Glen State Park
  12. Lake Placid
  13. Brooklyn Bridge

  15. The Bronx Zoo
  16. Ausable Chasm
  17. Corning Museum of Glass
  18. Lake George
  19. Darwin D. Martin House Complex
  20. Cooperstown

1: Times Square

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/MK Feeney
  • Rate attraction:
  • 156
    14
  • View Map

Times Square, the bustling commercial center at the intersection of Broadway and 7th Avenue, is often called the Crossroads of the World, and it certainly lives up to that nickname.

It sees one million new people every three days making it one of the most visited tourist attractions in New York State.

It glows day and night with neon advertisements and signs, giving the streets a carnival atmosphere. Here you'll find the TKTS booth, selling discounted tickets for hot Broadway shows.

There is also a wealth of shopping to do at Forever 21, and Planet Hollywood and the Hard Rock Cafe are also located nearby, adding to the spectacle.

Address: Broadway, New York City, NY 10036

Also Read: Top 10 Tourist Attractions in New York City

2: Statue of Liberty

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/William Warby
  • Rate attraction:
  • 154
    16
  • View Map

"Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free." These famous lines came from a poem celebrating this monumental symbol of freedom.

The neoclassical marvel was a gift from France to the United States in 1886 and is probably one of the best-known statues in the world.

Visitors to Liberty Island, where the statue resides, can choose to enjoy the sight from the ground or ascend to the crown for an unparalleled view.

The statue can't help but inspire no matter how it is observed. It stands as a reminder of its role as the first face to greet immigrants coming to America to seek a better life.

Address: Liberty Island, NY

Website: www.nps.gov

3: Niagara Falls

Photo Courtesy: Dreamstime/Mykyta Starychenko
  • Rate attraction:
  • 124
    14
  • View Map

Niagara Falls is actually a series of three waterfalls which, when taken together, send more water cascading over the edge than any other falls in the world. They straddle the United States and Canada, with waterfalls being visible on both sides of the border.

With the increasing availability of boat tours like Maid of the Mist, it became more accessible to the public, making it a popular honeymoon destination.

Its superlative nature has inspired some of the more death-defying stunts ever pulled in the 20th century, with people going over the edge in barrels or walking on tightropes across it. It seems that Niagara can't help but capture the imagination of anyone who sees it.

Address: 24 Buffalo Avenue, Niagara Falls, NY, 14303

Also Read: 10 Best Things To Do In And Around Niagara Falls, New York

4: Metropolitan Museum of Art

  • Rate attraction:
  • 78
    24
  • View Map

New York City is America's unofficial capital because of places like this: the Met, as it's commonly known, is the largest museum in the United States.

It contains artworks from all over the world and all throughout history, like those of ancient Egypt and Greece, or the European masters of painting, or various collections from Asia, Oceania, and Africa.

The collection even goes back to the Neolithic era with cuneiform tablets and Bronze Era artifacts. Much of the world is represented here in one way or another, making the Met truly the people's art museum.

Address: 1000 5th Ave, New York City, NY 10028

Website: www.metmuseum.org

Also Read: Top 5 Most Visited Museums In New York City

5: Central Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Anthony Quintano
  • Rate attraction:
  • 97
    17
  • View Map

The design of this sprawling urban green space was inspired by architect Frederick Law Olmsted's frequent visits to major European cities where parks of its kind were commonly found.

Hansom cabs are a popular transportation mode through the park, adding to the European feel. Ride the famous carousel, stop in at the Central Park Zoo, or marvel at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre.

At any time of year, but certainly in the warmer months, Central Park is alive with activity and music, and there are so many sculptures and curiosities that to truly experience all of what it has to offer takes multiple days.

Address: 14 E 60th St, Central Park Conservancy, New York, NY 10022

Website: www.centralparknyc.org

Also Read: What's So Special About New York City?

6: Hudson Valley

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Kyle Garrity
  • Rate attraction:
  • 52
    12
  • View Map

The Hudson Valley surrounds the Hudson River between its endpoints in New York City and the Albany area. This gorgeous stretch of fertile ground contains hiking trails, rock climbing, whitewater rafting, fishing, as well as shopping, and museums detailing the stories of the region.

There is something to do in the valley all year round, with autumn being a particular favorite because of the changing of the leaves.

World-class restaurants specializing in locally sourced farm to table cuisine line the valley and beckon tourists to immerse themselves in their Hudson Valley experience.

Address: Hudson Valley, NY

7: Letchworth State Park

  • Rate attraction:
  • 59
    8
  • View Map

Also known as the "Grand Canyon of the East," Letchworth State Park sits on the Genesee River and several of its tributaries. The river carved a deep gorge out of the rocks, and the result is breathtaking natural beauty for miles.

Waterfalls dot the river and its creeks, with the highest waterfall in New York State, Inspiration Falls, residing here.

People come to the park to enjoy hiking, hunting, fishing, whitewater rafting, snowmobiling, cross country skiing, camping, and whatever else can be done when the weather's right.

Address: 1 Letchworth State Park, Castile, NY 14427

Also Read: 10 Best State Parks in the United States

8: Adirondack Mountains

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Jonathan Miske
  • Rate attraction:
  • 43
    12
  • View Map

This curious mountain range does not follow a tectonic path like the Rockies or the Cascades in the West. These mountains are actually parts of one large dome that was raised due to geological unrest underneath.

Their beauty is unique, and it attracts outdoor enthusiasts of all kinds. Canoers and kayakers have multiple bodies of water to choose from.

Hunting and fishing, though strictly regulated, are enjoyed by many. Rock climbers, bird watchers, and snowmobilers can all find happiness here.

The Wild Center in Tupper Lake provides a wealth of information about the natural history of the surrounding area and is open year-round.

Address: Adirondack Mountains, NY

Also Read: Top 10 Things To Do In The Adirondacks

9: Thousand Islands

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/iloveny
  • Rate attraction:
  • 54
    8
  • View Map

This collection of islands in the St. Lawrence River actually numbers closer to 2,000, although some of them are just barely big enough to support a single tree. Some islands belong to Canada and some to the United States, New York specifically.

In addition to the beautiful scenery of the area, there are a number of attractions here, including Boldt Castle on Heart Island, which was built by one man out of adoration for his wife.

The Antique Boat Museum gives the history of the area by way of boats that were built or sailed here. For those who scuba dive, the wreck diving here is purported to be some of the best in the world.

Address: 43373 Collins Landing Rd, Alexandria Bay, NY 13607

Website: www.visit1000islands.com

10: Finger Lakes

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Sue Reynolds
  • Rate attraction:
  • 40
    15
  • View Map

The Finger Lakes are so called because they are a series of long, thin bodies of water with a north-south alignment, resembling fingers. The two longest, Seneca and Cayuga, are almost 40 miles long.

The area is well suited for winemaking, and wineries are in abundance. There are also museums dedicated to the region's rich history, including the Womens Rights Natural Historic Park in Seneca Falls, where the women's suffrage movement began.

The Corning Museum of Glass, the Strong National Museum of Play, the Museum of the Earth, and the Seward House, named for President Lincoln's secretary of state, can all be found here.

Address: Finger Lakes, NY

Website: www.fingerlakes.org

11: Watkins Glen State Park

Photo Courtesy: Dreamstime/Sara Winter
  • Rate attraction:
  • 2
    0
  • View Map

Visit the Watkins Glen State Park to experience a beautiful natural setting home to lots of waterfalls. Established in 1906 in New York’s Finger Lakes Region, the park centers around a gorge formed by the Glen Creek. Much of the landscape was shaped by historic glacier activity to create a great area worth exploring.

Watkins Glen State Park is one of the best places to visit in New York State during the fall when you’ll get to see the colorful fall foliage. It’s a seasonal park open from May to November that offers excellent hiking opportunities for all ages.

There are three main hiking trails in the park. Hike the Gorge Trail to see the beautiful sight of 19 waterfalls cascading through the gorge. You cross over stone bridges and steps for accessibility for everyone. The other trails wind around the gorge rim to give you fantastic overview sights.

Address: 1009 N Franklin St, Watkins Glen, NY 14891

12: Lake Placid

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/diane cordell
  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0
  • View Map

Travel to the north of New York to visit Lake Placid, one of the most famous areas in the Tri-Lakes region. It’s most known for hosting the Winter Olympic Games in 1932 and 1980. It remains a popular destination for winter sports and touring the facilities used during the Olympics.

Lake Placid is a community built around the lake, tucked within the Adirondack Mountains. The landscape is perfect for enjoying outdoor activities in any season. During the winter, you can ski the slopes on Whiteface Mountain. During the summer, you can explore the mountainous region along several hiking and biking trails.

You’ll find plenty of boat rentals to take out into the lake for a few hours to enjoy the scenery. Gondola rides are also available to ride up the mountain for incredible views. As an alternative, take a scenic drive up to one of the highest peaks in the Adirondack Mountains range.

Address: Lake Placid, New York

13: Brooklyn Bridge

  • Rate attraction:
  • 2
    0
  • View Map

New York City is full of architectural wonders, and the Brooklyn Bridge is one of the highlights. It’s one of the most famous landmarks in NYC that you’ve undoubtedly seen in films and other media showcasing the city.

The Brooklyn Bridge is one of the must-visit New York attractions where you’ll get to travel between Manhattan and Brooklyn. The bridge was constructed in 1883 as the first of many bridges connecting the two boroughs. The bridge crosses over the East River at 1595.5-feet long and rises 127-feet above the water below.

The bridge is a common traffic passageway between the boroughs, but it’s also a popular place to walk and bike. It has dedicated lanes for pedestrians and cyclists. Many tourists visit to take photos from either side where you’ll have incredible views. It’s recognized as a National Historic Landmark for its architecture and one of NYC’s most recognized structures.

Address: Brooklyn Bridge, New York, NY 10038

14: Coney Island

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/John Gillespie
  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0
  • View Map

If you’re visiting NYC, take an hour train ride to reach the historic Coney Island, one of the top attractions in New York State. Coney Island is a neighborhood in Brooklyn located on the waterfront most known for its amusement parks.

Coney Island is a popular area for amusement park development with two current amusement parks onsite – Deno’s Wonder Wheel Amusement Park and Luna Park. There are a few miscellaneous rides that don’t belong to any specific park.

There are a few iconic rides on Coney Island, including the Wonder Wheel Ferris wheel, the Coney Island Cyclone, the last remaining wooden roller coaster in the state, and the B&B Carousel, a traditional-style carousel ride.

Coney Island is a fun place to escape the big city and have fun for all ages. It also features carnival-style games to win prizes.

In addition to the amusement park, Coney Island has a boardwalk lined with restaurants leading to the beach. It’s home to the famous Nathan’s Hot Dog.

Address: Surf Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11224

15: The Bronx Zoo

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Jeffrey
  • Rate attraction:
  • 2
    0
  • View Map

Ever since opening in 1899, The Bronx Zoo has been a favorite family-friendly activity while visiting New York. It’s the biggest urban zoo in the country, making it one of the top attractions in New York State. Over two million people visit the zoo every year.

The Bronx Zoo covers 265 acres featuring over 6,000 animals of 650 different species. The zoo is divided into several exhibitions representing diverse habitats. Some sections include Jungle World, World of Reptiles, Tiger Mountain, and the Africa Plains. It also has a Children’s Zoo and live animal encounters.

Some of the favorite animals to see in the zoo are gorillas, zebras, giraffes, Komodo dragons, lions, leopards, elephants, and sea lions.

Arrive at the zoo early to get a chance to explore as much of the park as you can. There are lots of restaurants and snack shops to spend an entire day at the zoo. Don’t forget to pick up a few souvenirs.

Address: 2300 Southern Blvd, The Bronx, NY 10460

16: Ausable Chasm

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Shelby L. Bell
  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0
  • View Map

The Ausable Chasm is a large gorge carved out by the Ausable River. It creates an incredibly scenic destination worth exploring while traveling in New York state. It’s located in the Adirondack Mountains and a favorite place to visit to enjoy nature.

Ausable Chasm has many things to do to explore than scenery, including nature trails, viewpoints, and waterfalls. It’s a popular place for hiking, rafting, rock climbing, and sightseeing.

Visitors can take adventure tours in the chasm for a guided experience and participate in the activities. You’ll get to hike along the river and climb into rafts to cruise down the choppy waters.

You’ll have a lot of incredible sights during your visit. One of the best landmarks to see is the Ausable Chasm Bridge, a picturesque arch bridge made of steel. It was completed in 1933 and listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

Visitors can stay overnight at designated campgrounds in the park.

Address: 2144 U.S. 9, Ausable Chasm, NY 12911

17: Corning Museum of Glass

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Thad Zajdowicz
  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0
  • View Map

Everything that you see in the Corning Museum of Glass is glass. The museum focuses on all things related to glass, including artistic designs, glass history, and the science behind glassmaking.

Corning Museum of Glass is located in Corning, New York, established by the Corning Glass Works company in 1951 during its 100th anniversary. The museum collection has grown to include over 50,000 glass pieces dating as far back as thousands of years.

The glass collections are arranged in multiple galleries and exhibitions. It displays glass from different eras, regions of the world, and techniques in the art of glassmaking. The entire museum is beautifully arranged with structures you might not even believe are made from glass.

The Corning Museum of Glass includes several engaging activities for its hundreds of thousands of visitors that come every year. It hosts live glassmaking demonstrations and lectures about glass. It’s one of the best places in the country to explore the wonders of the material.

Address: 1 Museum Way, Corning, NY 14830

18: Lake George

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/John
  • Rate attraction:
  • 2
    0
  • View Map

Lake George has always been one of the top getaway New York attractions that first welcomed the region’s wealthy, but now a place for everyone to visit. It’s a frequent summertime vacation spot or a fall retreat for visitors to enjoy outdoor recreation and scenic views around the lake.

Lake George is an elongated lake stretching over 32-miles long and only 1-3-miles wide. It was first discovered by early European explores who competed over the land with Native Americans during the French and Indian War. Its popularity grew thanks to its position along the waterway and railway between New York and Montreal.

Today, Lake George is a fun destination for water fun on the lake. Visitors can rent boats such as kayaks and paddleboats to ride around the lake. It also has steamboat cruises available.

Other activities include swimming and hiking around the lakeshores. Many visitors plan overnight trips to the lake and stay in the many accommodations in the Village of Lake George or camping.

Address: Lake George, NY

19: Darwin D. Martin House Complex

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/cp_thornton
  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0
  • View Map

Buffalo, NY, is home to one of the best works from famed architect Frank Lloyd Wright - Darwin D. Martin House Complex. Wright built several notable houses in the region, and the Martin House is a favorite out of the collection.

The Darwin D. Martin House Complex features multiple structures, all boasting a Prairie School era style. The complex was completed in 1905 after being commissioned by Darwin D. Martin, a successful businessman. The complex includes the main Martin House, conservatory, carriage house, gardener’s cottage, and more. It underwent significant restoration efforts and rebuilt.

Darwin D. Martin House Complex is now a tourist destination for visitors to walk through the impressive architectural feat. It has a visitor center where you can watch a short film about the architect and learn more about the house. You can then proceed on a guided or self-guided tour to explore the interior and grounds of the National Historic Landmark.

Address: 125 Jewett Pkwy, Buffalo, NY 14214

20: Cooperstown

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/duluoz cats
  • Rate attraction:
  • 2
    0
  • View Map

Considered the birthplace of baseball, Cooperstown is one of the best places to visit in New York State, especially for lovers of the game. Although a small village, it attracts many tourists looking to explore the local museums and historic districts.

Cooperstown is famed for the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum. Most people visiting the village stop by the museum during their trip to see an extensive collection of artifacts and exhibits about the sport. The hall of fame was established in 1939 and continued to induct players into the exclusive club.

After a visit to the museum, be sure to check out the Cooperstown Historic District. It includes over 200 buildings and listed on the National Register of Historic Places. A walk through the district showcases the incredible architecture of the traditional-style structures. Many of the buildings are converted into accommodations and restaurants.

Address: Cooperstown, NY

Vermont Top 10 Attractions

Home to the popular congressman Bernie Sanders, Vermont is a place that is very welcoming and has plenty to offer any tourist who is looking for a nice vacation. You get a great combination of natural landmarks, as well as plenty of historical and regional attractions.

Once you visit this beautiful state you’ll fall in love with the people, the places, as well as the undeniable charm all around you. Because Vermont is so rich in diversity and things to do, we’ve narrowed down some of our favorites into a checklist of the top 10 tourist attractions.

Best Places to Visit in Vermont

Table of Contents
  1. Ben & Jerry's Ice Cream Factory Tour
  2. Lake Champlain
  3. Shelburne Museum
  4. Smugglers Notch State Park
  5. Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historic Park
  6. Hildene, The Lincoln Family Home
  7. Montshire Museum of Science
  8. Killington Ski Resort
  9. Quechee Gorge
  10. Church Street Marketplace

1: Ben & Jerry's Ice Cream Factory Tour

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Qfamily
  • Rate attraction:
  • 207
    36
  • View Map

Learn and discover how one of the world's favorite ice cream brands is made. Ben & Jerry's 30-minute factory tour takes you through an educational experience where you learn about the ice cream manufacturing process.

Check out their full service scoop shop that includes some limited edition flavors and visit their gift shop to bring home some fun Ben & Jerry's memorabilia.

Address: 1281 Waterbury Stowe Rd, Waterbury, VT 05676

Website: www.benjerry.com

2: Lake Champlain

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Mobilus In Mobili
  • Rate attraction:
  • 73
    62
  • View Map

Everybody needs a good lake day! Lake Champlain, Vermont is a well-loved attraction amongst tourists and locals alike. It is a massive body of water situated in New York, Vermont, and even stretching into Quebec, Canada.

Lake Champlain is the proud destination for any wild number of activities. Such as, camping and hiking! Full of wide open air, crackling firewood and a view of the lake, there’s a reason these sites fill up fast.

If you’re more of an aquatic fanatic, then look into a boat tour. Boat tours are one of the best ways to experience Lake Champlain as you get to ride from corner to corner with the waves splashing all around you.

Lake Champlain is also a popular location for seasonal events and holidays. Most months have a bulletin posted for all that is going on and open to curious tourists. During Christmas, the holly jolly spirit is nearly tangible and during the summer there is always a little something celebrating the season.

Lake Champlain is the perfect spot to choose for a little serenity by the shores. Kick back, relax, and let the soothing sounds of lapping water do the rest.

Address: Lake Champlain, VT

3: Shelburne Museum

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/Shelburne Museum
  • Rate attraction:
  • 93
    28
  • View Map

Located in Vermont's picturesque Lake Champlain Valley, Shelburne Museum is known as one of America's most unconventional museums. Explore over 150,000 works of art that are displayed in 38 different exhibition buildings.

From folk art, impressionist painting and decorative art to furniture and textiles, you are going to step into a world of wonder and imagination right here at the Shelburne Museum.

Address: 6000 Shelburne Rd, Shelburne, VT 05482

Website: www.shelburnemuseum.org

4: Smugglers Notch State Park

  • Rate attraction:
  • 124
    57
  • View Map

Nestled high in the greenery of Vermont comes one of the best state parks in the country! Smugglers Notch State Park is a wide expanse of terrain open to campers, hikers, and bikers. The season typically ranges from May 17th till October 14th.

It features 20 tent sites as well as 14 lean-to sites and even allows certain pets on the trails! The campground is open every day from 2 till 8 p.m. It is a great place to stay if you want to get a jump on your hiking experience early. There’s nothing quite like falling asleep to the sounds of rustling leaves and the soothing sounds of nature.

At Smugglers Notch State Park, visitors are treated to some of the most incredible scenery available. There are 1,000 foot cliff drop-offs and little footpaths that wind and connect all about the park.

Found at the Notch, adventure seekers are also encouraged to participate in some of the best activities a season has to offer. For example there is bouldering, cave exploring, and even ice climbing found all within the same state park. Smugglers Notch State Park is one of the most popular destinations in Vermont for those with a passion for adventure!

Address: 6443 Mountain Rd, Stowe, VT 05672

Website: www.vtstateparks.com

Also Read: 10 Best State Parks in the United States

5: Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historic Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Nicki Dugan Pogue
  • Rate attraction:
  • 85
    15
  • View Map

Located to the right of the historic Burlington Waterfront, ECHO Lake Aquarium and Science Center lets you discover a whole new world. Kids will love exploring the aquarium's fantastic exhibits such as FrogWorld, Action Lab, and the Land of Opportunity.

You can participate in some of the children's and adult's programs that engages you in the ecology, culture and history of the Lake Champlain Basin.

Address: 54 Elm St, Woodstock, VT 05091

Website: www.nps.gov

6: Hildene, The Lincoln Family Home

  • Rate attraction:
  • 60
    27
  • View Map

The Lincoln Family home was built in 1905 in the scenic village of Manchester. Today it is one of Vermont's top attractions where thousands of visitors are welcomed to the grounds and walking trails.

The house visit starts with a brief video presentation followed by a self-guided tour. Make sure to drop by the Cutting and Kitchen Gardens, Hildene Farms to visit the animals, the Observatory, the exhibits and the gift shop for some souvenirs.

Address: 1005 Hildene Rd, Manchester, VT 05254

Website: www.hildene.org

7: Montshire Museum of Science

  • Rate attraction:
  • 57
    13
  • View Map

Dive into science at the Montshire Museum in Vermont! This location is one of the top destinations in the state for unique and educational exhibits ranging from a wide array of topics. It is one of the leading institutions for technology, ecology, and several other divisions.

The Indoor Discovery exhibits range from discovering the natural world to the wonder that is bubbles or even testing a science discovery lab. Outside is the David Goudy Science Park. There are 100 acres of lush Vermont nature to explore, and several hands-on outdoor exhibits to spend the day at.

Aside from holidays, the Montshire Museum of Science in Vermont is open every day. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., this location is open to the public. General admission is $16 for adults and $13 for children aged 2-17. During the summer season (late June to Labor Day) admission is $18 for adults and $15 for children aged 2-17. Children under 2 are always guaranteed free admission.

If you are a true science enthusiast, look into some of the multi-day passes available for purchase. There is more than enough here to make this a several day excursion. Get a good deal and let your imagination run wild!

Address: 1 Montshire Rd, Norwich, VT 05055

Website: www.montshire.org

8: Killington Ski Resort

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/specialolympicsusa
  • Rate attraction:
  • 50
    7
  • View Map

Cool off and have some unadulterated fun at this hugely popular ski resort. Killington has the largest resort of its kind on the east coast, actually, and one of the largest vertical slopes.

There are six major peaks that provide a good variety of challenge, as well as plenty of breathtaking views of the natural surroundings.

Killington Ski Resort is fun for the home family, offering plenty of ways to enjoy the snow-capped environment, while providing plenty of comfort and safe activities.

Address: 4763 Killington Rd, Killington, VT 05751

Also Read: Top 10 Ski Resorts in the USA

9: Quechee Gorge

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/angela n.
  • Rate attraction:
  • 52
    17
  • View Map

The Quechee Gorge is the deepest gorge in all of Vermont! It is 165 feet deep and acts as one of the most popular destinations for tourists from all over the country.

People come from far and wide to experience something as unique as this landmark. The campground in Quechee Gorge is open from 10 a.m. until sunset. The campsite features 45 tent or RV sites as well as 7 lean-to sites.

Quechee Gorge is also notable for being in close proximity to numerous upper-valley activities. It is the perfect place to venture to on your trip to Vermont as you can not only see all the magnificence of this site, but continue on your way to even more fun.

At Quechee you can hike, bike, stroll, and trail blaze as miles upon miles of well-loved Vermont nature opens up to you.

Address: Quechee Gorge, Hartford, VT

Website: www.quecheegorge.com

10: Church Street Marketplace

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Collin Parker
  • Rate attraction:
  • 75
    46
  • View Map

Shop till you drop in the heart and soul of Burlington! The Church Street Marketplace is the number one destination in the city for all things downtown. You can go from café to boutique without missing a beat. Finish it all off with some of the best cuisine found in the state! Vermont is already known for serving up a mouth-watering dish, and Church Street has come to deliver that and more.

There are several different ways to experience this attraction. Opt for a guided walking tour, or make your own bucket list! Go to the waterfront to sit back and relax, or pour up at a Vermont brewery to keep the good times rolling. There is even a lively nightlife scene that keeps Burlington lively and exciting.

Regardless of the season, Church Street Marketplace is open for business. However, there are some special dates found on the website calendar that make this an unforgettable treat. Several times throughout the year, Church Street will celebrate the best in the arts with an Artist Market. Select Saturdays from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. the streets are painted with the kind of local art you just can’t find anywhere else.

There are also holiday celebrations for the likes of Thanksgiving and Christmas that bring the whole community together. Shops found in the Marketplace will often participate too. With decorations and seasonal-specific treats and souvenirs that tourists and locals just can’t get enough of. There is always something to celebrate on Church Street!

Address: 2 Church St, Burlington, VT 05401

Website: www.churchstmarketplace.com
