1: Harpers Ferry National Historical Park

  • Rate attraction:
  • 135
    72
  • View Map

When you visit the Harpers Ferry National Historical Park, you can look forward to taking a step back in time as you explore the rich history. This is a diverse West Virginia attraction with something for everyone from fascinating museums and exhibitions to hiking areas and battlefields.

You can enjoy strolling around the historic town, which is located within the national park as well as taking in the stunning surrounding beauty, which makes it ideal for nature lovers as well as those interested in the historical side of the attraction.

With close to half a million visitors annually, this is a very popular place to visit in West Virginia and provides you with an enlightening and educational day out.

Address: 171 Shoreline Dr, Harpers Ferry, WV 25425

2: Snowshoe Mountain

  • Rate attraction:
  • 87
    20
  • View Map

West Virginia is a popular wintertime destination for winter sports lovers. Many people have plans set to visit Snowshoe Mountain, the most popular ski resort in WV. It features 60 slopes, some of which were developed by an Olympic skier for a world-class skiing experience.

Unlike many other ski resorts, Snowshoe mountain is established on the top of the mountain. While Snowshoe Mountain is the resort name, it’s located within the Allegheny Mountains, which gets plenty of snowfall, so it’s perfect. During the winter, visitors can enjoy skiing, snowboarding, and other winter sports. It has routes for all skiing levels and also provides lessons for beginners.

It’s also a summer destination popular for mountain biking, golfing, ATVs, and other activities.

While taking a break from the slopes, the resort is a massive complex to explore. It’s a part of the Village at Snowshoe, where you’ll have additional perks, such as dining, a spa, shopping, and more.

Snowshoe Mountain is a destination for the entire family and one of the top attractions in West Virginia.

Address: 10 Snowshoe Dr, Snowshoe, WV 26209

Also Read: Top 10 Ski Resorts in the USA

3: West Virginia State Penitentiary

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/andrewbain
  • Rate attraction:
  • 91
    47
  • View Map

A visit to this Gothic style former prison is well worth adding to your itinerary when you are visiting West Virginia. The prison was opened in the late 1870s and continues operating until the mid-1990s. It has a rich and often dark history sometimes involving breakouts and riots.

You will be fascinated when you take a tour of the prison as you can enjoy the thrill of mystery along with the chance to explore the history of the penitentiary.

There are also special events held here such as Zombie Walks, Kids’ nights and even mock prison riots. This is an attraction that is certain to leave a lasting impression on visitors, so it is definitely one you shouldn’t miss.

Address: 818 Jefferson Ave, Moundsville, WV 26041

Website: www.wvpentours.com

Also Read: Top 10 Most Haunted Places In The United States

4: Seneca Caverns

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/Seneca Caverns WV
  • Rate attraction:
  • 104
    48
  • View Map

Once used for Seneca Indian ceremonies, the Seneca Caverns in West Virginia provide a fascinating insight into the past. You will find touring these cavers to be an exciting and unique experience, as you can delve into their long history as well as take in the fascinating surroundings.

There are many tour options available for visitors to the caverns, and there are plenty of great facilities that you can benefit from, such as the restaurant, a gift shop, and even picnic areas.

Visitors are thrilled to see the breathtaking rock formations that can be found here, and you can even try some gemstone mining and bring home unique memories of your visit.

It’s one of the unique things to do in West Virginia, full with fun, excitement, and plenty of activities.

Address: 3328 Germany Valley Rd, Riverton, WV 26814

Website: www.senecacaverns.com

Also Read: Top 10 Most Amazing Caves & Caverns in the USA

5: New River Gorge Bridge

Photo Courtesy: Adobe Stock/Patrick Jennings
  • Rate attraction:
  • 112
    31
  • View Map

There’s no denying the magnitude of the New River Gorge Bridge. It was seen as a huge architectural feat when it was completed in 1977. In total, the bridge cost nearly 37 million dollars and used 22,000 tons of structural steel in its construction.

Today, it stands as one of the highest bridges in the United States. The 876-foot steel arch bridge exudes picturesque views of the surrounding Appalachian Mountains and is one of the most photographed places in West Virginia.

Visitors are securely fastened to a safety cable, making it a safe and enjoyable two to three-hour Bridge Walk tour.

It should definitely be on your list of places to visit in West Virginia!

Address: 130 Laurel Creek Rd, Fayetteville, WV 25840

6: West Virginia State Capitol

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Mobilus In Mobili
  • Rate attraction:
  • 48
    19
  • View Map

The government seat for this state, the West Virginia State Capitol, is part of a historic complex and is home to the office of the Governor of West Virginia as well as the West Virginia Legislature. It can be found in the Charleston area, and the whole district has been listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

This is a striking building with fascinating architecture, including a breathtaking 293-foot gold dome. It also boasts a grand and decadent interior, much of which is marble, while the outside is constructed from steel and limestone. You can also enjoy exploring the rest of this historical complex during your visit.

Coming to the West Virginia State Capitol is one of the best things to do in Charleston.

Address: 1900 Kanawha Blvd. East, Charleston, WV 25305

Also Read: Top 10 Tourist Attractions in Charleston, West Virginia

7: Summersville Lake

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Todd Neal
  • Rate attraction:
  • 49
    11
  • View Map

Summersville Lake is one of the best places to visit in West Virginia for the holidays or a weekend getaway during the summer. It’s West Virginia’s largest lake with a shoreline extending more than 60 miles.

Summersville Lake is a reservoir created by the Summersville Dam completed in 1966. It was built for flood control but became a popular recreation area. It’s a destination to enjoy the outdoors for all ages.

Some of the favorite activities to do at the lake include kayaking, rock climbing, swimming, and fishing. There are many places around the lake for jumping off the rocks into the water. Diving and snorkeling are also common. Divers can explore depths up to 327-ft and even catch a glimpse of a sunken boat.

The water levels of Summersville Lake change by the season. In the low water levels, many people choose to hike one of the many trails surrounding it. Trails provide scenic views of the lake from all angles. You can even reach the Summersville Lake Lighthouse overlooking the lake.

Address: 278 Summersville Lake Road, Mount Nebo, WV 26679

8: Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Lwp Kommunikáció
  • Rate attraction:
  • 46
    22
  • View Map

One of the most famous and historical psychiatric hospitals in America is located in West Virginia. The Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum is a popular tourist attraction, many of which have heard about the strange paranormal activity happening within the walls. It offers lots of tours and experiences for brave tourists.

Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum features admirable architecture in a Gothic Revival style from the 19th Century. It was used as a psychiatric hospital until 1994 and is now recognized as a US National Historic Landmark. Its tours have become well-known thanks to multiple features in pop culture media.

Visitors can experience various tours around the property. One of the main tours is a general guided tour to see multiple hospital rooms, apartments for the nurses, and other facilities. The first floor features a museum exhibiting artworks by the patients created during art therapy.

Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum specializes in ghost and paranormal tours. You’ll get to experience the dark side of the mental hospital and even stay overnight to see if you can survive until the morning.

It’s one of the spookiest things to do in West Virginia.

Address: 71 Asylum Dr, Weston, WV 26452

Also Read: Top 10 Most Haunted Places In The United States

9: Stonewall Jackson Lake Resort

  • Rate attraction:
  • 51
    17
  • View Map

For more luxurious accommodations than camping in Stonewall Jackson Lake State Park, the Stonewall Jackson Lake Resort is the perfect option. The resort is your gateway to having the best experience in the state park for a destination that combines comfort with outdoor fun.

Stonewall Jackson Lake Resort is a family-friendly resort that delivers luxury lodge accommodations for guests. The lodge has upgraded facilities and modern rooms that make you feel at home in the natural setting. You’ll find resort features such as a swimming pool, spa, an onsite restaurant, and golf course, but perhaps the most fun is within the park.

Stonewall Jackson Lake State Park is established around the Stonewall Jackson Lake, a large lark with more than 82 miles of shoreline. It’s considered one of the most scenic West Virginia attractions thanks to the preserved environment.

You can find lots of things to do at the lake, including boating, fishing, and hiking. There is a marina to rent kayaks and canoes.

Address: 940 Resort Drive, Roanoke, WV 26447

10: Blackwater Falls State Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Nicolas Raymond
  • Rate attraction:
  • 104
    39
  • View Map

The most famous park in West Virginia is the Blackwater Falls State Park, known for the Blackwater Falls. The park is a favorite attraction for locals and tourists – you’ll find everyone from young kids to elders enjoying the park thanks to its accessibility. Walk the nature trails to the top sights and enjoy the incredible scenery.

Blackwater Falls is a 62-ft tall cascade waterfall flowing from the Blackwater River into the Blackwater Canyon. The name derives from the naturally dark waters, and the unique style of the falls makes it the most photographed waterfall in West Virginia. The best time to see the falls is from spring to fall (it’s frozen during the winter).

Visitors can explore multiple hiking trails leading to the Blackwater Falls to see it from different perspectives. Other points of interest include Lindy Point Overlook, Elakala Falls, and a nature center with information about the park’s natural history. Other common activities include mountain biking and skiing in the winter. Campgrounds are also available.

Address: 1584 Blackwater Lodge Rd, Davis, WV 26260

Also Read: 10 Best State Parks in the United States

11: Seneca Rocks State Park

Photo Courtesy: USDA/Kelly Bridges
  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0
  • View Map

Stand at the parking lot of the Seneca Rocks State Park, and you’ll see the picturesque Seneca Rocks emerging from above the Monongahela National Forest. Seneca Rocks is one of the best places to visit in West Virginia for rock climbing. For those who reach the top, you’ll be rewarded with incredible views.

Seneca Rocks State Park has a three-mile hiking trail leading from the parking lot to the top of the cliff. Thanks to the hiking trail, it’s great for all ages, but many people prefer the climbing challenge.

Seneca Rocks is over 1,500-ft high – it has 375 climbing routes on different faces that range in difficulty. Once you reach the top, you’ll have panoramic views of the lush green landscape of the state park.

There are several other activities to do in the state park after conquering the rock. It’s an excellent place for hiking, fishing, horseback riding, and picnics. Also, be sure to stop by the visitor center for more information about the park and visit the historical museum.

Address: Seneca Rocks, WV

12: The Greenbrier

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/The Greenbrier
  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0
  • View Map

The award-winning Greenbrier’s grand façade is a historic landmark and modern accommodation to give you an incredible experience during your stay in West Virginia. The five-star luxury resort preserves its traditional heritage while offering many amenities and services for entertainment on its vast grounds.

The Greenbrier was founded in 1778 and rebuilt in the early 1900s. Ever since it first opened, it has been an upscale resort to welcome international visitors and several past US presidents. It features more than 700 rooms, 20 restaurants, and dozens of shops. It is located on 11,000 acres of scenic manicured lawns and untouched nature.

You’ll have a cozy stay in one of the guestrooms and suites showcasing warm traditional décor with modern amenities. Many of the rooms have incredible views of the surrounding landscape.

Popular activities include checking out the museum, playing on the tennis courts, playing around on the golf course, or trying your luck at the casino. There are lots of things to do for all ages that keep the resort ranked on the top in West Virginia.

Address: 101 W Main St, White Sulphur Springs, WV 24986

13: Cass Scenic Railroad State Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Ron Cogswell
  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0
  • View Map

West Virginia formerly had a significant lumber industry, one who's heritage is well preserved by West Virginia attractions like the Cass Scenic Railroad State Park. The park's highlight is the Cass Scenic Railroad, a logging railway-turn-tourist attraction where you'll get to explore the region's legacy.

Cass Scenic Railroad State Park encompasses Cass, a company town established in 1901 to support the local logging industry. It’s a historical town full of renovated homes and stores where you’ll get to explore much of its history. Visit the visitor center for more information on local tours into the various buildings.

The railway was once used for transporting logs, but now gives visitors a chance to discover the scenic landscape. It offers two tours – travel to the Whittaker Station and back; take a round-trip to the Bald Knob summit, the highest point in West Virginia.

The train ride provides fantastic scenery, and the views at the summit are breathtaking. It stops for a short break to grab photos before returning to the station.

Address: 12363 Cass Rd, Cass, WV 24927

14: Monongahela National Forest

Photo Courtesy: USDA/Kelly Bridges
  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0
  • View Map

The Monongahela National Forest is one of the most important forests in West Virginia. Located in the Allegheny Mountains, the national forest designation protects over 900,000 acres of forest land. It’s known for its diverse spruce trees and many of West Virginia’s highest mountain peaks.

Monongahela National Forest is one of the top attractions in West Virginia, with over three million visitors annually. It has a diverse landscape with 75 species of trees and an extensive wilderness area.

It’s a popular place for outdoor recreation with lots of things to do in the forest. Some of the common activities include hiking, biking, rock climbing, horseback riding, boating, and fishing. The forest features more than 800 miles of trails to various viewpoints and points of interest – Spruce Knob, Bear Creek, and High Falls.

The forest also has several campgrounds used for overnight stays. Backpacking is also permitted for exploring the backcountry.

Address: 200 Sycamore St, Elkins, WV 26241

15: Coopers Rock State Forest

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/jcsullivan24
  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0
  • View Map

West Virginia has several destinations for scenic views of the beautiful landscape. One of the popular spots is in Coopers Rock State Forest, a place known for some of the state's best viewpoints.

Coopers Rock State Forest is divided into a northern and a southern section, split by a major interstate highway. It has natural scenery, outdoor recreation, and historical places to check out during your visit.

One of the highlights of the forest is the Cheat Canyon overlook. Visitors can drive up to the viewpoint for picturesque views of the Cheat River and even see Morgantown in the distance. If you’re up for a hike, the Raven Rock overlook is another excellent option for excellent views.

There are many hiking trails leading to the viewpoints and several buildings included on the list of National Register of Historic Places within the forest. Other popular activities include rock climbing and skiing during the winter. The forest also has seasonal campgrounds available.

Address: 61 County Line Dr, Bruceton Mills, WV 26525

16: Hawks Nest State Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Anthony G. Reyes
  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0
  • View Map

One of the best viewpoints of West Virginia’s scenic landscape is from a bird’s eye view. Hawks Nest State Park offers visitors precisely that - it’s a prominent overlook of the New River. It’s a fun Park to visit in any season to see the continually changing foliage and enjoy recreational activities.

Main Overlook is the leading destination in Hawks Nest State Park. Located just off the highway, you’ll be perched on top of the cliff towering 750-ft above the New River. It’s the best viewpoint of the river where you’ll also see the surrounding forest landscape.

Many sites developed around the overlook, including a lodge for guest stays, a museum, and a restaurant. Visitors can ride the gondola ride between the summit and the river shore below.

Hawks Nest State Park is also a place to get active. It has several hiking trails leading up to the overlook or the natural landmarks like waterfalls and the creek. You can learn a lot about the natural environment in the River Nature Center.

Address: 49 Hawks Nest Rd, Ansted, WV 25812

17: Appaachian National Scenic Trail

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/anokarina
  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0

The Appalachian National Scenic Trail is one of the most well-known hiking trails in the US. It extends from Maine to Georgia and passes directly through West Virginia, which many people consider the midpoint. More than two million people make the 2,200-mile hike every year, and you’ll get to experience just a sample of it while visiting West Virginia.

Appalachian National Scenic Trail extends for four miles in West Virginia, and a portion of the trails is located on the West Virginia-Virginia border. It’s a well-marked trail all accessible to hikers of all skill levels. The trail highlights some of the scenic natural landscape in West Virginia as you attempt to hike across the country.

The Appalachian Trail Conservancy is located in Harpers Ferry, one of the main hubs along the trail. It’s where visitors can get lots of information about the trail and even chat with experts to learn about the region.

Whether you get the chance to hike the entire trail or just the section in West Virginia, it’s worth it to say you did it!

18: Green Bank Observatory

  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0
  • View Map

West Virginia has the ideal location for viewing into outer space thanks to low inference and pollution. The Green Bank Observatory serves a primary purpose for space observation and research but has become a fun place for adults and kids to learn about astronomy.

Green Bank Observatory was established in 1956 in Green Bank but didn’t start operating until 1958. It’s the former headquarters for the National Radio Astronomy Observatory but has since begun to operate independently.

The observatory has multiple radio telescopes for measuring radio waves received from space. The Green Bank Telescope is the largest fully steerable radio telescope in the world at 300-ft. The other telescopes are smaller but just as helpful in space observation.

Visitors are welcome to explore the observatory grounds and facilities. You can take a guided tour, including a ride into the restricted areas, to see the telescopes up close. The site also consists of a Science Center and exhibition hall where you can sit in on lectures.

Without a doubt, the Green Bank Observatory is one of the most unique tourist attractions in West Virginia.

Address: 155 Observatory Rd, Green Bank, WV 24944

19: Mothman Museum

  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0
  • View Map

Sometimes, it takes a small urban legend to transform an obscure town into a bustling destination for tourists. That's the case with Point Pleasant whose Mothman myth continues to draw curious travelers to the sightings' location. If you're interested in seeing yourself, whether it's a myth or fable, explore the local attractions, including the Mothman Museum.

Mothman was first spotted near Point Pleasant in 1966 and additional sightings over the next year. The event was widely reported nationally, leading to many pop culture features. It is when the small myth transformed into one of the main local attractions.

Today, you'll find many things to do in Point Pleasant devoted to the Mothman. The Mothman Museum is one of the best places to learn more about the mysterious creature. The museum exhibits old newspaper articles and eyewitness accounts. Be sure to check out the gift shop to find lots of Mothman souvenirs.

The town has a life-size Mothman statue outside of the museum and also hosts an annual event for the creature.

Address: 400 Main St, Point Pleasant, WV 25550

Website: www.mothmanmuseum.com

20: Charleston Capitol Market

  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0
  • View Map

Charleston is the capital of West Virginia and a popular city to explore for visitors. One of the top tourist attractions in Charleston is the Capitol Market. It’s a favorite market for locals and visitors to find lots of local goods and produce for any occasion.

Capitol Market is established in an old train station with vendors set up indoors and outdoors. The market sells various items, including fresh produce, seafood, and seasonal goods like decorations and plants. You’ll even find some fantastic souvenirs to take home.

Bring your appetite because there is plenty to eat in the market. Capitol Market features vendors selling ready-to-eat dishes, and there is also a restaurant to dine in.

The market runs every day year-round. It's a fun place to get a feel for the local atmosphere, especially during the holiday season. It's one of the most festive places to prepare for holidays and upcoming seasons.

Address: 800 Smith St, Charleston, WV 25301

Arkansas Top 10 Attractions

Have you been feeling bored and restless at work? Why not do something fun and spontaneous by packing your bags and heading to an exciting new place you have never been to before? One of the most visited places in the country is the gorgeous state of Arkansas. You, your family and your friends will have a lot of things to see and do here. If you are currently thinking of making Arkansas your next travel destination, here are the top 10 attractions that you should visit.

Best Places to Visit in Arkansas

Table of Contents
  1. Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art
  2. Hot Springs National Park
  3. Magic Springs and Crystal Falls Water and Theme Park
  4. Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site
  5. Little Rock Zoo
  6. Clinton Presidential Center
  7. Thorncrown Chapel
  8. Arkansas Air & Military Museum
  9. Crater of Diamonds State Park
  10. Garvan Woodland Gardens

1: Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art

  • Rate attraction:
  • 131
    24
  • View Map

If you are looking for an attraction that offers culture and access to some excellent artwork displays, the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art is a great choice. The museum is set in stunning grounds, so you can also enjoy the opportunity to take in the natural beauty of the area as well as the various exhibitions.

The museum provides access to permanent exhibits as well as temporary ones. The permanent collection contains artwork that goes back up to five centuries so lovers of arts and culture are in for a real treat when visiting this attraction.

Address: 600 Museum Way, Bentonville, AR 72712

Website: www.crystalbridges.org

2: Hot Springs National Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Joe Shlabotnik
  • Rate attraction:
  • 94
    45
  • View Map

Heat up your vacation with a little time in the Hot Springs National Park in Arkansas! This is one of the most popular destinations, and for good reasons. It is often nicknamed “America’s Spa” or some variation of ‘a staple mark in the name of United States hot springs attractions’.

Still not convinced? What might draw your eye is the price tag. 100% free! The entrance fee, a ticket to the historic museum, and even a guided tour are all on the house! The only thing you’ll have to pay for here is a $10 cover charge if you plan on camping overnight.

Hot Springs National Park is open daily from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. It features over 45 individual hot springs to explore, and diverging paths that wind and flow from site to site. However, and as tempting as it may be, there are no hot springs available for public use here.

The water ranges anywhere over 140 degrees Fahrenheit. Which means it is not meant for the human body to be submerged. That’s not to say you can’t still enjoy it from the outside.

The Hot Springs are a beautiful natural phenomenon to explore and marvel at no matter what time of year you find yourself in Arkansas! Be sure to stop by and see what all the raving reviews are about.

Address: Hot Springs National Park, Hot Springs, AR 71901

Website: www.nps.gov

Also Read: Top 5 Tourist Attractions in Hot Springs, Arkansas

3: Magic Springs and Crystal Falls Water and Theme Park

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/Magic Springs and Crystal Falls
  • Rate attraction:
  • 74
    51
  • View Map

Craving for some thrill, action and adventure? Magic Springs and Crystal Falls Water and Theme Park has it all for you. Enjoy some of the most breathtaking thrill rides like the Arkansas Twister, Plummet Summit and the Sky Shark.

If you are visiting the park with your kids, check out some family-friendly rides like the Rum Runner Pirate Ship, Razorback Roundup Bumper Cars and the Diamond Mine Coaster.

You can also spend a few hours at the water park where you can splash your way through thrilling slides, exciting wave pools, and relaxing lagoons.

Address: 1701 E Grand Ave, Hot Springs, AR 71901

Website: www.magicsprings.com

4: Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Adam Jones
  • Rate attraction:
  • 59
    28
  • View Map

Come see where history was made! The Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site is just as it sounds. It is both a functional high school, as well as an operating testament to the legacy of American history.

It was here that nine brave schoolchildren changed the fate of America forever. With the 1957 desegregation crisis at its peak, Little Rock was truly watched by the nation as it helped pioneer the civil rights movement.

Considering this is still an active high school, there are a few things you’ll need to know before visiting. Firstly, that you can only view this site as a part of a reserved guided tour. Guided tours are only offered on the select days as dictated by the official website.

These tours will take place at 9 a.m. and 1 p.m. Guided tours also take a minimum of 24 hours to process, and visitors will not be allowed to tour without confirmation.

Therefore, it is typically recommended interested parties call somewhere in the realm of a month before. To allow ample time to make accommodations, check dates, and confirm your spot. As a true marker of American history, this is one stop you’re going to want to make time for.

Address: 1500 Park Street, Little Rock, AR 72202

Website: www.nps.gov

Also Read: Top 10 Tourist Attractions in Little Rock, Arkansas

5: Little Rock Zoo

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Arkansas ShutterBug
  • Rate attraction:
  • 87
    17
  • View Map

Explore the animal kingdom in Arkansas’s title zoo! Here in Little Rock, this attraction is home to over 700 animals. They vary from species to species, and average in at over 200 different representations of all things wildlife.

Check out exhibits of monkeys, apes, lions, tigers, and bears (oh my), and so much more all within a sprawling 33 acres of Arkansas real estate.

It is even funded by the Arkansas Zoological Foundation, which promotes the development of the zoo as a whole. Here animals are treated with care, and provide for the perfect day entertainment for some good ole fashioned family fun.

The Little Rock Zoo in Arkansas is even known for hosting celebrations and events! Check out the official calendar on the website for some of their title attractions. These include things like ‘Breakfast with the Penguins’, ‘Lion Day’, and ‘Zoo Brew’.

This zoo also hosts other gatherings such as weddings, birthday parties, and group events. Even if you’ve just come for a regular day of Arkansas adventure, you’re sure to find some golden memories.

Tickets here range from approximately $13 for adults, and $10 for youths. However, the Little Rock Zoo is also known to host an ‘annual day’ wherein all tickets are just $1 per person! Be sure to stay updated online for this special occasion, and enjoy one of Arkansas’ best attractions for cheap.

Address: 1 Zoo Dr, Little Rock, AR 72205

6: Clinton Presidential Center

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Ed Schipul
  • Rate attraction:
  • 28
    38
  • View Map

For a really diverse, fascinating and educational day out, a visit to the Clinton Presidential Center is a must. There are plenty to see and do here, as you take in the many sights, attractions and facilities on this seventeen acre site.

You will be able to browse a range of educational exhibits and take tours, experience the inside of the Oval Office and take a seat at the Resolute Desk, pay a visit to the Clinton Museum Store, and enjoy lunch at the onsite restaurant amongst other things. The center also offers a variety of educational programs with various camps and activities for different ages.

Address: 1200 President Clinton Ave, Little Rock, AR 72201

Website: www.clintonfoundation.org

Also Read: Top 10 Tourist Attractions in Little Rock, Arkansas

7: Thorncrown Chapel

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Thorncrown Chapel
  • Rate attraction:
  • 49
    22
  • View Map

Towering at forty-eight feet, Thorncrown Chapel enjoys a wonderful setting tucked away in woodland. This is an architectural masterpiece, which opened in 1980. Its unique design and beauty have resulted in the chapel being awarded a variety of architectural awards.

It is a building that is both inspirational and spectacular in terms of its design, with millions of people having visited since it opened.

Those who want to pay a visit to this eye-catching religious structure will find that there is plenty of parking available. Better still, there is no admission fee but donations are gratefully received.

Address: 12968 U.S. 62, Eureka Springs, AR 72632

Website: www.thorncrown.com

8: Arkansas Air & Military Museum

Photo Courtesy: Wikimedia/Michael Barera
  • Rate attraction:
  • 34
    8
  • View Map

The Arkansas Air & Military Museum is home to vintage aircrafts ranging from the golden era of aviation to the jet era. The exhibits in the museum displays variety of military vehicles, aircraft, and artifacts.

Some of the aircrafts in the museum are the country's only surviving varieties of aircraft that belong to the golden era of aviation as well as World War I. This museum is definitely worth the visit if you are any kind of history or aircraft buff.

Address: 4290 S School Ave, Fayetteville, AR 72701

Website: www.arkansasairandmilitary.com

Also Read: Top 5 Tourist Attractions in Fayetteville, Arkansas

9: Crater of Diamonds State Park

Photo Courtesy: Wikimedia/Doug Wertman
  • Rate attraction:
  • 68
    41
  • View Map

Known as the only diamond-producing site in the world that is open to the public, the Crater of Diamonds State Park provides you with a unique experience that you will never forget.

Hunt through more than 37 and a half acres of plowed field which is the eroded surface of an ancient volcanic crater.

If you are lucky, you might chance upon diamonds and some semi-precious stones that were brought about by the eruption of a volcano some 100 million years ago.

Address: 209 State Park Rd, Murfreesboro, AR 71958

Website: www.craterofdiamondsstatepark.com

Also Read: 10 Best State Parks in the United States

10: Garvan Woodland Gardens

  • Rate attraction:
  • 57
    23
  • View Map

Experience the ethereal beauty of Arkansas with the Garvan Woodland Gardens! And with this location, it’s important to note that there is a lot to explore.

The Garvan Woodland Gardens is a massive 210 acre reserve nestled in the heart of Arkansas. It is owned and operated by the University of Arkansas, and dazzles visitors no matter what time of the year they may come.

There are sloping lush green hills with all sorts of berries and bushes, and trickling rivers that flow through this testament to natural terrain beauty.

Garvan Woodland Gardens is typically $15 for adults, $5 for children below 12, and free for ages 0-3. And even dogs are allowed entry, for the low price of $5 (just make sure they are leashed!).

Also, this superb Arkansas pride is open every day from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.! That means 9 full hours open to make the most out of your entrance ticket.

It is important to note that the Garden is closed on the holidays of Thanksgiving and Christmas, as well as the month of January. Aside from that, it’s happy trails!

Address: 550 Arkridge Rd, Hot Springs, AR 71913

Kentucky Top 10 Attractions

From raging waterfalls to racing horses, Kentucky is a state chock full of adventure! It is a tourism hot spot for incorporating just a little bit for everyone.

Those looking to answer the call of the wild will be mystified by the magnificence that is two state of the art National Parks. Those who want to dance with lady luck will find their fun at the Churchill Downs, famous for the Kentucky Derby. And those in search of some spirituality will find entertainment in the Creation Museum.

Here are the top 10 attractions in Kentucky that you should not miss.

Best Places to Visit in Kentucky

Table of Contents
  1. Mammoth Cave National Park
  2. Churchill Downs
  3. Kentucky Horse Park
  4. Cumberland Falls State Resort Park
  5. Daniel Boone National Forest
  6. Creation Museum
  7. Shaker Village of Pleasant Hill
  8. Louisville Zoo
  9. Newport Aquarium
  10. Kentucky Kingdom and Hurricane Bay

1: Mammoth Cave National Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Margaret River
  • Rate attraction:
  • 264
    65
  • View Map

Mammoth Cave National Park is an outdoor enthusiast’s oasis! It is a state-renowned gem that features some of the best camping, hiking, and exploration in all of Kentucky. Mammoth Cave is even a UNESCO World Heritage site, and has been referenced by many famous travelers and adventure magazines.

Perhaps its most popular draw comes in the form of the famed cave tours. Deep within the natural beauty of Mammoth, visitors are taken by foot or water to marvel at Mother Nature’s hidden gems. Weaving through the complex layer of caves, these tours will bring you up close and personal to something you can seldom seem elsewhere. Jaws drop, pictures are snapped, and Mammoth earns its spot as one of the top tourist attractions in Kentucky.

The hours of the Mammoth Cave National Park depend on the season of arrival. During spring and summer, the park is open every day from 8 a.m. till 6:30 p.m. During fall the hours are 8 a.m. till 6 p.m., and during winter from 8:30 a.m. till 4:30 p.m. Entrance into the park itself is free, however you’re going to want to use the money you saved here on some of those magnificent cave tours. Happy trails!

Address: 1 Mammoth Cave Pkwy, Mammoth Cave, KY 42259

Website: www.nps.gov

2: Churchill Downs

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Jeff Kubina
  • Rate attraction:
  • 148
    34
  • View Map

On your mark, get set, go! The Churchill Downs in Louisville makes for one of the top tourist attractions in not just Kentucky, but the South! Its classic name to fame is the annual hosting of the Kentucky Derby. Every year thousands of tourists and locals flock to the Churchill Downs to experience one of the greatest days in all of Derby history. If you’re a fan of the race, be sure to get in early! The Kentucky Derby is one of the most anticipated events in Louisville and can often fill up fast.

As exhilarating as the Kentucky Derby is, it’s just the tip of the Churchill Downs iceberg. Every week during September meet, this location hosts “Twilight Thursdays.” Admission is just $5, doors open at 4 and there is live music, draft deals, and even food trucks! What more could you want in a Thursday? If beer isn’t your beverage of choice, maybe check out the famed “Bourbon and beats.” When the lights go down, Churchill Downs lights up and experiences some of the best in cocktails, racing, and music. And if your beverage of choice is juice: check out the Family Adventure Day in October. Every year, the Churchill Downs hosts this celebration of all things fun and family. It’s a great way to explore the facilities with kid-friendly activities at every turn.

Whatever day, race, or celebration you choose: be prepared to saddle up for some serious Kentucky action! The Churchill Downs is one place that never disappoints.

Address: 700 Central Ave, Louisville, KY 40208

Website: www.churchilldowns.com

Also Read: Top 10 Tourist Attractions In Louisville, Kentucky

3: Kentucky Horse Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Bobbie Galiotos
  • Rate attraction:
  • 114
    33
  • View Map

If you have always been fascinated by horses, the best place to visit would be the Kentucky Horse Park. Their Horses of the World display will allow you to discover different breeds of horses through a breathtaking show filled with colors and sounds.

If this is your first time to go horseback riding, you can enjoy a 35-minute guided trail ride. If you have kids who would love to try out riding, they can go on Pony Rides around the pony paddock.

Address: 4089 Iron Works Pkwy, Lexington, KY 40511

Website: www.kyhorsepark.com

4: Cumberland Falls State Resort Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Aaron Vowels
  • Rate attraction:
  • 144
    42
  • View Map

The majestic Cumberland Falls holds a number of fun activities for you and your family. You can go gem mining and discover some real, colorful and beautiful gemstones at the gemstone flume. You can also go birding and discover some of the most exquisite bird species such as the Pileated Woodpecker or the Wood Thrush.

If you love roughing it up at the great outdoors, you can set up camp at any of the park's 50 campsites complete with electricity and water hookups.

Address: 7351 KY-90, Corbin, KY 40701

Website: www.parks.ky.gov

5: Daniel Boone National Forest

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Edgar P.
  • Rate attraction:
  • 83
    20
  • View Map

Tourism in Kentucky just isn’t complete without mentioning ways to appreciate its natural beauty. The Daniel Boone National Forest is the perfect place for visitors to immerse themselves in the lush luxuries of the great Kentucky wilderness. There is so much to see here, from steeping green hills to breathtaking rushing waterfalls.

The Cumberland Falls is famous for its “moonbow” which draws hundreds of tourists to its banks monthly. The Daniel Boone National Forest is predominately marked by two well-known campsites. The Little Lick Campground and the Holly Bay Campground are fantastic places to set up camp for the night if you really want to see what this national forest is all about.

Aside from hiking, the Daniel Boone National Forest also features boating and target shooting. To assure your spot underneath the starry sky, make a reservation online! It is $9 per site online, and $10 by way of call service. It is important to note that reservations are exclusively catered towards the summer recreation season. With good reason! As stunning as this location is no matter the weather, summer is really the time to go for ease of trip and less layers.

This is a massive stretch of land from all corners, so it is highly recommended to stay more than one day. Check out some of the trail maps, or make it a ‘decide as you go’ adventure. All compasses point straight to Daniel Boone National Forest for some of the best hiking paths in Kentucky.

Address: 1700 Bypass Rd, Winchester, KY 40391

Website: www.fs.usda.gov

6: Creation Museum

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/David Berkowitz
  • Rate attraction:
  • 112
    101
  • View Map

Getting as close to “heaven on Earth” as is allowed, the Creation Museum is one of the most unique attractions in Kentucky. This is one of the few museums in the world that details the works of creationism in such an interactive way.

There are numerous exhibits to explore, and even more historical telling’s featured all around the complex. The Creation Museum creates a place to experience the Christian religion in an immersive and educational setting. Found in Williamstown, Kentucky, this location is the proud host to thousands of guests throughout the year.

And it is so much more than just a museum! The Creation Museum is also a planetarium, a zip line adventure course, a petting zoo, and more. Take a stroll through the heavenly botanical gardens or take a seat in the state of the art theater.

The Creation Museum is a destination with so much to offer! It is open every day from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m., excluding Sunday. On Sunday, the museum is open from 12 till 6 p.m. Ticket prices range by age and are as follows: adults: $35, seniors: $30, youth (11-17): $25, Children(5-10): $15, and below 4 is free. From exhibits to exploration, this is one of the top tourist attractions in all of Kentucky.

Address: 2800 Bullittsburg Church Rd, Petersburg, KY 41080

Website: www.creationmuseum.org

7: Shaker Village of Pleasant Hill

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/shakervillageky
  • Rate attraction:
  • 65
    30
  • View Map

The Shaker Village is where you will get to experience Kentucky's rich history and heritage. Explore the Living History Museum to meet the men and women who have called the village their home for over 100 years.

Visit the farm and garden to discover Shaker Hill's traditional ways of growing and harvesting fresh produce. If you want to challenge yourself and enjoy nature, you can hike, bike or run through the village's 30-mile trail system, which features fantastic landscapes that you would love to take photographs of.

Address: 3501 Lexington Rd, Harrodsburg, KY 40383

Website: www.shakervillageky.org

8: Louisville Zoo

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Sreejith K
  • Rate attraction:
  • 67
    13
  • View Map

This zoo is one of the most visited attractions in all of Kentucky. Explore some of their award-winning animal exhibits such as the Glacier Run where you will encounter Polar Bears and Grizzly Bears; the Gorilla Forest where you will discover a multi-faceted rotational exhibit allowing you to go deep into the realm of a gorilla's natural habitat.

Your kids will also enjoy a day of learning and exploration about animal and nature conservation through the Backyard Action Hero program.

Address: 1100 Trevilian Way, Louisville, KY 40213

Website: www.louisvillezoo.org

Also Read: Top 10 Tourist Attractions In Louisville, Kentucky

9: Newport Aquarium

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/newportaquarium
  • Rate attraction:
  • 73
    13
  • View Map

Named as the number one aquarium in the 2012 Reader's Choice Travel Awards, the Newport Aquarium is where you will get to have a first-hand encounter with some of the most exotic sea creatures like sharks, fish, jellyfish, and stingrays.

Walk through a gigantic aquarium and feel like you are actually swimming with the magnificent sharks. Your kids will enjoy the Penguin Encounters where they can actually touch, interact with and play with the friendly penguins.

Address: 1 Aquarium Way, Newport, KY 41071

Website: www.newportaquarium.com

10: Kentucky Kingdom and Hurricane Bay

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Ken Stanek
  • Rate attraction:
  • 90
    9
  • View Map

If you think a vacation is not complete without a visit to a theme park then you should make sure to drop by Kentucky Kingdom and Hurricane Bay. This park offers extreme rides that will thrill you and take your breath away.

Go on the FearFall ride that will drop you from a towering 129 feet at an exhilarating 45-mile per hour speed. Watch a show at their 5D cinema to have a viewing experience that is just totally out of this world.

The Hurricane Bay water park also offers you some fun under the sun with their Plummet Summit and their Tornado Ride, as well as some rest and relaxation at the Lazy River.

Address: 937 Phillips Ln, Louisville, KY 40209

Website: www.kentuckykingdom.com

Mississippi Top 10 Attractions

Mississippi is an exciting state full of natural beauty, historic landmarks, and cultural attractions. This state is known as both the Magnolia State and the Hospitality State, giving a hint of the warm reception you'll get when visiting Mississippi.

Heading to the state capital, 'Jackson' will show you museums and other attractions, but heading to the area by the Mississippi Delta is perfect when you want to enjoy some American forests.

There are family-friendly attractions such as theme parks and zoos and educational ones such as historic sites, or you can simply enjoy the Gulf Coast for water activities.

Let's explore the top 10 attractions in Mississippi you must visit.

Best Places to Visit in Mississippi

Table of Contents
  1. Vicksburg National Military Park
  2. Mississippi Museum of Natural Science
  3. Natchez Trace Parkway
  4. Gulf Coast Beaches & Water Activities
  5. Jackson Zoological Park
  6. Gulf Islands Waterpark
  7. Elvis Presley Birthplace
  8. Tupelo National Battlefield
  9. Marine Life Oceanarium
  10. Riley Center

1: Vicksburg National Military Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/faunggs photos
  • Rate attraction:
  • 278
    75
  • View Map
Once you get to the Vicksburg National Military Park, the first thing that you need to do is to drop by the visitor center to plan out your entire day's visit. Watch a 20 minute orientation to learn more about the park's history then check out a fascinating outdoor exhibit that includes a Cannon Display, the Fortification Exhibit as well as Historic Monuments. After your visit you will have a greater appreciation for American History and for all the brave souls who fought during the civil war.

Address: 3201 Clay St, Vicksburg, MS 39183

Website: www.nps.gov

Also Read: Top 10 American Civil War Sites To Visit

2: Mississippi Museum of Natural Science

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/Mississippi Museum of Natural Science
  • Rate attraction:
  • 232
    37
  • View Map
Located in Jackson, this 73,000-square foot complex introduces you to a world of exciting exhibits, nature trails and an open-air amphitheater. Here you will enjoy a series of life-size displays like the Monsters of the Deep exhibit as well as a 1,700-square foot gigantic greenhouse aptly called The Swamp. Children will enjoy their interactive aquarium where they can handle live marine creatures and learn more about how to conserve the environment.

Address: 2148 Riverside Dr, Jackson, MS 39202

Website: www.mdwfp.com

Also Read: Top 10 Tourist Attractions in Jackson, Mississippi

3: Natchez Trace Parkway

Photo Courtesy: Wikimedia/Brent Moore
  • Rate attraction:
  • 200
    43
  • View Map
You can take a ride through time at the Natchez Trace Parkway. The iconic 444-mile national parkway winds through the original Natchez Trace trail, which was first walked by prehistoric migrating animals. The two-lane road rolls through some of the most scenic parts of the southeastern U.S. You’ll roll through protected areas of Tennessee, Alabama and Mississippi en route to some beautiful waterfalls and hiking trails. Natchez Trace is also home to many historic sites including the Meriwether Lewis Museum and Mount Locust. Today the parkway is one of the top attractions in Mississippi where you can explore challenging trails, go biking, horseback riding and even camping for an overnight stay or two.

Address: Natchez Trace Parkway, Natchez, MS 39120

Website: www.nps.gov

Also Read: Top 7 Tourist Attractions in Natchez, Mississippi

4: Gulf Coast Beaches & Water Activities

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Visit Mississippi
  • Rate attraction:
  • 163
    58
  • View Map
Looking to soak up the sun? Look no further than the Mississippi Gulf Coast. It’s home to 62 miles of picture perfect shores and sandy beaches. While kicking back on the beach is the preferred method, there are many ways to experience the area. You can cure your wanderlust with an island excursion to West Ship Island. It’s renowned for being a go to spot to enjoy the Gulf Coast’s warm waters. Or you can try your hand at paddle boarding, kayaking, or canoeing. The Mississippi Gulf Coast is also known for having top-level restaurant and shopping experiences.

Address: 1716 Beach Blvd, Biloxi, MS 39531

5: Jackson Zoological Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/NatalieMaynor
  • Rate attraction:
  • 179
    37
  • View Map
The Jackson Zoo is currently home to 776 animals from 120 different species. Take your children here so they can get up close and personal with their favorite exotic animals. Get on the replica steam train, which can take you around the park to observe the animals in their natural habitats. Let your kids join the Zoo Camp where they will learn more about the animals and what they can do to help conserve them.

Address: 2918 W Capitol St, Jackson, MS 39209

Website: www.jacksonzoo.org

6: Gulf Islands Waterpark

  • Rate attraction:
  • 146
    14
  • View Map
This water park is one of the things that you definitely should not miss during your trip to Mississippi. Check out the Master Blaster which is the Gulf Coast's first and only water roller coaster. It will take you through an extremely thrilling 500 feet slide filled with breathtaking twists and turns. The Cat Island Catapult and the Lil Pelican's Bay are great for younger kids where they can splash around and play with fun water cannons.

Address: 17200 16th St, Gulfport, MS 39503

Website: www.gulfislandswaterpark.com

7: Elvis Presley Birthplace

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/Elvis Presley Birthplace
  • Rate attraction:
  • 107
    39
  • View Map
If you have always been fascinated by the life of the musical genius Elvis Presley, then this is one place that you should not dare miss. The tour will take you through the "Walk Of Life" which is a concrete circle surrounding the house where the King was born. You will then visit the Elvis Presley Museum where you can observe some of the personal collections of Elvis's longtime friend Janelle McComb. End your tour at the Gift Shop where you can bring home with you some unique souvenirs from the tour.

Address: 306 Elvis Presley Dr, Tupelo, MS 38804

Website: www.elvispresleybirthplace.com

8: Tupelo National Battlefield

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Ron Cogswell
  • Rate attraction:
  • 73
    21
  • View Map
The historic battle of Tupelo happened in 1864 when Union Forces marched into Tupelo and fought fiercely with the Disorganized Confederate soldiers. Today the park is home to a monument that includes two informational panels explaining the significance of the battle. If you have always been fascinated by American history, then this park should be on your must-visit list.

Address: Tupelo, MS 38801

Website: www.nps.gov

9: Marine Life Oceanarium

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/Marine Life Oceanarium
  • Rate attraction:
  • 134
    13
  • View Map
Discover an exciting and enchanting world under the sea as you visit the Marine Life Oceanarium at the Institute for Marine Mammal Studies. Here, you will get to enjoy a hands-on learning experience and interact with unique sea creatures at the Discovery Room's touch pools. Enjoy watching different types of dolphins at the Dolphin Presentation and sign in for a one-of-a-kind Dolphin Encounter.

Address: 10801 Dolphin Ln, Gulfport, MS 39503

Website: www.imms.org

10: Riley Center

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Visit Mississippi
  • Rate attraction:
  • 69
    26
  • View Map
You can see a modern show in a historic setting at the Riley Center. Also known as the Grand Opera House, the Riley Center is a performing arts center located in a fully restored grand opera theater house. The theater originally opened in 1890. Today, it’s a 30,000 square foot facility with an exhibit hall, boardrooms, conference center, and meeting place. You can enjoy a show in either their expansive 950-seat opera house theater or the more intimate 200-seat studio theater. The Riley Center features legendary Romanesque and Victorian architecture and is renowned as one of the best places to see a show in the southeast.

Address: 2200 5th St, Meridian, MS 39301

Website: www.msurileycenter.com

Tennessee Top 20 Attractions

It’s one of America’s fastest growing states, Tennessee is the perfect mix of modernization, natural surroundings, and cultural soul that keeps everything grounded. The people here are as charming as the sights and sounds that make up Tennessee.

Want a good place to connect with your inner Zen? Take a trip to the Smoky Mountains and witness some of the most breath-taking views in America. Why not stroll down the Mississippi River and be entranced by both the river bed and the wonderful restaurants that thrive off it.

In Tennessee, if you aren’t dancing, nodding your head, or tapping your foot to the rich and diverse music scene then you might be born without a heartbeat. Listen to the heart and soul of America in Nashville or Memphis, where you’ll fall in love with music all over again.

It’s perfectly natural to want to move to Tennessee once you’ve visited. When you make your itinerary for your trip make sure to include the following top 20 attractions in Tennessee.

Best Places to Visit in Tennessee

Table of Contents
  1. The Smokies: The Great Smoky Mountains National Park
  2. Elvis Presley's Graceland
  3. Grand Ole Opry House and Opry Museum
  4. Tennessee Aquarium
  5. Dollywood
  6. The Hermitage: President Andrew Jackson's Home
  7. Memphis Zoo and Aquarium

  20. Crystal Shrine Grotto

1: The Smokies: The Great Smoky Mountains National Park

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/rftrudeau
  • Rate attraction:
  • 134
    24
  • View Map

Visit Gatlinburg to reach the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, one of the largest national parks in the Eastern Region of the US. Established in 1940, the park protects sections of the Great Smoky Mountains and parts of the Blue Ridge Mountains.

The beautiful landscape predominantly consists of forested areas with various elevations – it features a very diverse ecosystem with approximately 19,000 species of plants, animals, and other organisms.

This is the country's most visited national park – over 11 million people visit the park every year. The park is a destination for sightseeing and recreation.

There are several points of interest in the park - Clingmans Dome is an observation tower at the highest point. There are also lots of historical landmarks such as log cabins and churches.

Tourists enjoy visiting the park for recreational activities, including hiking, cycling, horseback riding, and fly fishing. A section of the famous Appalachian Trail runs throughout the park for hiking enthusiasts.

Address: 107 Park Headquarters Rd, Gatlinburg, TN 37738

Accomodation: Where to stay near Great Smoky Mountains National Park

Website: www.nps.gov

Also Read: Top 10 Things To Do In Great Smoky Mountains National Park

2: Elvis Presley's Graceland

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Holly Hayes
  • Rate attraction:
  • 97
    34
  • View Map

If you find yourself in Memphis, be sure to visit Elvis Presley’s Graceland, the second-most visited home in America (after the White House). The impact of Elvis’s music remains a staple in pop culture, and now, his former mansion is available to the public for fans and tourists to get a glimpse into his extravagant lifestyle.

Elvis Presley’s Graceland opened as a museum in 1982, recognized on the National Register of Historic Places list and a National Historic Landmark.

Over half a million tourists visit the estate every year, enjoying the tour experience through the home. Visitors can take an audio guide tour of the mansion to learn more about the singer’s life, explore memorabilia, and see preserved rooms with original furnishing.

A highlight to visit the mansion is seeing the burial location of Elvis and other family members. There are other features of the museum experience, including an exhibition complex, a graffiti wall, and exploring his personal jets.

Every year, Graceland hosts Elvis Week, a weeklong celebration of the ‘King of Rock and Roll’ with events, speakers, and more.

Address: 3734 Elvis Presley Blvd, Memphis, TN 38116

Accomodation: Where to stay in Memphis

Website: www.graceland.com

Also Read: Top 10 Memphis, Tennessee Tourist Attractions

3: Grand Ole Opry House and Opry Museum

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Ron Cogswell
  • Rate attraction:
  • 54
    26
  • View Map

One of the many things that Tennessee is known for is its music and in Nashville, the musical heart of this state, you will find the Grand Ole Opry House and Opry Museum.

The Grand Ole Opry House is a purpose built, spectacular venue that hosts incredible stage entertainment based on an hour long radio barn dance founded in 1925. People from all around the world come here to enjoy the musical extravaganzas and performances.

Just to the right you will also find the Opry Museum, where you will find a huge variety of memorabilia on display and where entry is totally free of charge. Any music and entertainment fans will enjoy their visit to this attraction.

Address: 2804 Opryland Dr, Nashville, TN 37214

Accomodation: Where to stay in Nashville

Website: www.opry.com

Also Read: Nashville, Tennessee Top 10 Attractions

4: Tennessee Aquarium

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/Tennessee Aquarium
  • Rate attraction:
  • 64
    16
  • View Map

The Tennessee Aquarium in Downtown Chattanooga is ranked among the best aquariums to visit in the US. It opened in 1992, where it showcased the world’s biggest freshwater aquariums, exhibiting nearly 800 different species of marine life. Today, the aquarium expanded to include another building full of aquarium attractions.

Tennessee Aquarium has two dedicated aquarium buildings – River Journey and Ocean Journey. Some of the themed exhibitions in River Journey include ‘Rivers of the World,’ featuring species from notable rivers with the famous electric eel; ‘Delta Country,’ with species from the Mississippi River; and ‘River Giants,’ featuring the aquarium’s big fish and reptiles.

The largest aquarium tank is the ‘Secret Reef’ attraction in Ocean Journey. It’s home to various species of sharks and sea turtles. The aquarium also exhibits different penguin species in the ‘Penguin Rock’ section.

Tennessee Aquarium is a place for education and research, offering many public conservation activities and programs. It also features off-site activities such as boat tours in the Tennessee River and a 3D IMAX Theater experience.

Address: 1 Broad St, Chattanooga, TN 37402

Accomodation: Where to stay in Chattanooga

Website: www.tnaqua.org

5: Dollywood

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/Dollywood
  • Rate attraction:
  • 69
    17
  • View Map

If you’re looking for a fun family day out in Pigeon Forge, Tennessee one great place to visit is the theme park owned by country singing sensation Dolly Parton.

Dollywood is a fabulous place that is packed with attractions, entertainment and thrills ranging from a variety of exciting rides and a water park through to music, entertainment, events and plenty of facilities including accommodation.

The Southern Gospel Museum and Hall of Fame can also be found here, which is an added bonus for music fans. This is a delightful attraction that has something for all ages, making it the perfect family attraction.

Address: 2700 Dollywood Parks Blvd, Pigeon Forge, TN 37863

Accomodation: Where to stay in Pigeon Forge

Website: www.dollywood.com

Also Read: 10 Best Theme Parks in the US

6: The Hermitage: President Andrew Jackson's Home

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Jason Raia
  • Rate attraction:
  • 36
    11
  • View Map

Now a National Historic Landmark, the Hermitage was once the home of America’s seventh president, Andrew Jackson. The mansion, gardens and historic plantation are now part of a museum complex where you can enjoy exploration, education and history.

You can pay a visit to the mansion where you explore the displays and exhibits as well as learn more about the history of the property.

Take some time to explore the Hermitage plantation and the stunning gardens as well as the slave sites, outbuildings and the Hermitage Church.

You can also visit Jackson’s tomb, which is a fascinating structure that is located at the Hermitage site.

Address: 4580 Rachels Ln, Nashville, TN 37076

Website: www.thehermitage.com

7: Memphis Zoo and Aquarium

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Carl Wycoff
  • Rate attraction:
  • 49
    2
  • View Map

The Memphis Zoo and Aquarium are some of the main tourist attractions in Memphis. With the aquarium located inside of the zoo, a general admission ticket permits entry to both areas.

The Memphis Zoo was founded in 1906 as part of the Overton Park. It’s a top-ranking zoo in the United States, attracting over one million visitors annually and home to thousands of animals.

Some of the most popular species in the zoo include a giant panda, lions, giraffes, grizzly bears, sea lions, elephants, gorillas, and eagles.

The zoo features three zones divided into 19 exhibits, each designed as the natural habitat for the animals for an authentic viewing experience.

Visitors can stop by the aquarium to see additional exhibits of freshwater and saltwater marine life—the tanks host over 150 species from all over the world.

There are guided tours available for touring the zoo, as well as tram rides for more accessibility. The zoo and aquarium are open year-round with special events hosted at various times and seasonal decorations for holidays.

Address: 2000 Prentiss Pl, Memphis, TN 38112

Website: www.memphiszoo.org

8: Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum
  • Rate attraction:
  • 49
    7
  • View Map

Nashville is country music headquarters. So it makes sense that the Country Music Hall of Fame be located right in the heart of the city. The museum is an impressive ode to the music that put Nashville on the map.

The museum features 350,000 square feet of galleries, instruments, and artifacts that have had an influence on the country music genre. Nicknamed the “Smithsonian of country music”, the Country Music Hall of Fame is the world’s largest music museum.

It includes two large theaters, the Taylor Swift Education Center, and a rotating list of world-class exhibits.

Address: 222 5th Ave S Nashville, TN 37203

Website: www.countrymusichalloffame.org

Also Read: Nashville, Tennessee Top 10 Attractions

9: Titanic Museum

  • Rate attraction:
  • 60
    9
  • View Map

The Titanic Museum is truly a sight to behold, as the museum is actually shaped like the ill-fated liner that sank back in 1912. This is a museum with two floors and twenty galleries, which means that it is the biggest permanent Titanic museum on earth.

There are hundreds of artifacts to take in and you will enjoy an experience that will make you feel as though you were actually one of the passengers on the original vessel.

You can learn about some of the actual passengers that were on the original Titanic and the museum is actually located in a pool so that you are surrounded by water when you board, which makes for an even more authentic experience.

Address: 2134 Parkway, Pigeon Forge, TN 37863

Website: www.titanicpigeonforge.com

10: Ruby Falls

Photo Courtesy: Facebook/Ruby Falls
  • Rate attraction:
  • 75
    28
  • View Map

Ruby Falls is one of the hidden gems in Tennessee. Lookout Mountain is located just outside of Chattanooga, where visitors will discover the naturally formed caves. Explore the Ruby Falls cave, and you’ll find the stunning Ruby Falls hidden within it - it’s an underground cascade waterfall with an elevation of 145-feet.

Ruby Falls is one of the first commercially developed caves in the US, opened to the public in the 1930s. It’s designed for tourists and widely promoted as one of the best tourist destinations in the region.

There is a visitor center located in the landmark Cavern Castle where tourists can book reservations for the cave tour.

The guided tour walked groups through the lighted caves before emerging into the open space where the falls flow continuously. The experience features lights illuminating the falls in a variety of colors and music.

The tours provide lots of information about the history of Ruby Falls and a chance to take amazing photos of the landmark.

Address: 1720 South Scenic Highway, Chattanooga, TN 37409

Website: www.rubyfalls.com

11: Tennessee Civil War National Heritage Area

  • Rate attraction:
  • 3
    0
  • View Map

Tennessee played a significant role in the US Civil War, being a prominent conflict state. The history of the war is preserved in various regions of the state to make up the Tennessee Civil War National Heritage Area.

Tennessee Civil War National Heritage Area was designated in 1996, consisting of eight main regions. River regions include the Tennessee River, the Mississippi River, and more. Railroad regions include the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad, the Memphis and Charleston Railroad, and others.

Tourists can visit multiple destinations within each region, including historical sites, landmarks, and monuments. The purpose of these sites is for telling the story of the Civil War and retracing history.

There are over 400 markers and signs for the Tennessee War Trails, making it easy to identify each location.

The official Heritage Center opened in 2006 in Murfreesboro. It’s open to the public with free entry to find more information about the Tennessee Civil War National Heritage Area or to attend events hosted by the center.

Address: 1416 E Main St, Murfreesboro, TN 37130

Accomodation: Where to stay in Murfreesboro

Website: www.nps.gov

12: The Parthenon

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Michael McCarthy
  • Rate attraction:
  • 4
    1
  • View Map

The Parthenon is an impressive work of architecture located in Nashville. It was built in 1897 as the centerpiece of the Centennial Park for an exposition honoring Tennessee’s 100th anniversary as part of the union. It’s the only remaining structure from the explosion, now converted into an art museum.

The Parthenon is a full-size replica of the original building in Athens, Greece. The amazing architectural wonder renders the original color and interior details. It was chosen because of Nashville’s nickname as the ‘Athens of the South.’

Visitors can enjoy taking photos of the exterior before entering inside to see the permanent and temporary exhibitions hosted at the site. The most famous sculpture in the museum is a replica of the Athena Parthenos statue, another feature from the original building.

The main gallery features American art from the 19th and 20th Centuries.

Address: 2500 West End Ave, Nashville, TN 37203

13: American Museum of Science and Energy

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/Tom Sawyer
  • Rate attraction:
  • 2
    0
  • View Map

Oak Ridge was developed as a site for scientists during WWII to construct an atomic bomb. The American Museum of Science and Energy is a local science museum dedicated to energy sources, including nuclear power.

American Museum of Science and Energy opened in 1949, relocating and renamed from its original location. It houses permanent and rotating exhibitions showcasing various aspects of science and energy. Some of the exhibits include atomic discovery, nuclear weapons, a solar energy demonstration, a weather station, and robots.

The museum is a must-visit destination for visitors in Oak Ridge because of the interactive exhibitions and a walk-through attraction. Adults and kids can remain engaged for hours or a full day experience.

Oak Ridge played a significant role in the Manhattan Project, for building the atomic bomb. The museum offers bus tours to see several of the original sites of the project. The experience also includes a film documentary about the history of the atomic bomb and the project.

Address: 115 E Main St, Oak Ridge, TN 37830

Accomodation: Where to stay in Oak Ridge

Website: www.amse.org

14: Tennessee Valley Railroad Museum

Photo Courtesy: Flickr/David Brossard
  • Rate attraction:
  • 2
    0
  • View Map

Railroads are an essential part of Tennessee’s history. In essence, the Tennessee Valley Railroad Museum was founded in 1960 in Chattanooga to support the efforts of preserving the rich railroad history in the state. The museum includes one of the heritage railroads – a former railroad preserved in its original state.

The overall purpose of the museum is to showcase the rich train culture that existed in the region. It accomplished the goal with several things to do for visitors.

Tourists can see a display of six vintage steam locomotives exhibited in the museum. It includes a large rail yard and railroad equipment used to build the trains and railways. The museum features a locomotive repair shop, used for the restoration of the railcars.

One of the best parts of visiting the museum is riding on the historic trains. Visitors can climb aboard the vintage locomotives for a one-hour loop experience or a half-day journey across the region. The train ride provides excellent views, authentic train service, and even a railcar dedicated to kids’ activities.

Address: 4119 Cromwell Rd, Chattanooga, TN 37421

Website: www.tvrail.com

15: Lookout Mountain

  • Rate attraction:
  • 3
    0
  • View Map

Lookout Mountain serves as the backdrop to Chattanooga, being the cities most visited site. It’s the highest point in the county, with sections extending into Georgia and Alabama. Lookout Mountain is a historical site for notable war battles and now a major tourist destination for incredible views and recreation.

Lookout Mountain has an elevation of nearly 2,400-feet. The mountain includes natural landmark sites such as Ruby Falls, Sunset Rock, “Rock City” formations, and more. It also features several Civil War landmarks, as it was the site of the Battle of Lookout Mountain.

Visitors will have some of the best views atop Lookout Mountain. It provides sweeping views of downtown Chattanooga. One of the unique viewpoints is at “Rock City” – on clear days, viewers can see seven states at once.

One of the favorite recreational activities at the mountain is hiking. The hiking trails are pet-friendly and lead past historical sites of the mountain - you can learn a bit of history along the ascent to the summit.

Address: Chattanooga, TN 37409

Website: www.lookoutmountain.com

16: Beale Street

  • Rate attraction:
  • 3
    0
  • View Map

Beale Street is an iconic street in Memphis and a must-visit for everybody, whether local or tourist. The road extends for just under 2-miles, starting at the Mississippi River and ending at East Street. The entire strip is filled with history, culture, music, and nightlife.

Beale Street is the location where the Blues music genre was created. The historic district in Downtown Memphis became a hub for upcoming African American musicians and a social site for the public. As it continued to develop, it transitioned into one of the most famous places to visit in Memphis.

Visitors can enjoy a mix of activities on Beale Street during the daytime and night. During the day, it’s a great place for sightseeing and exploring its history – some of the notable landmarks include the Beale Street Baptist Church, the Memphis Rock n Soul Museum, the New Daisy Theatre, and a range of cafes and restaurants.

At night, Beale Street is the premier nightlife destination in Memphis. The street illuminates with neon lights shining from the bars and lounges lining the streets.

Address: Memphis, TN 38103

Website: www.bealestreet.com

17: The Lost Sea Adventure

  • Rate attraction:
  • 2
    0
  • View Map

Not all attractions in Tennessee are above ground – visit the city of Sweetwater to uncover one of the best underground attractions. The Lost Sea Adventure takes visitors on a journey to see the largest underground lake in the US. The cave-dwelling experience is excellent for adults and kids.

The Lost Sea Adventure requires guided tours through the cave system before reaching the lake. Set aside a couple of hours to visit the attraction. It starts with a hike up a steep hill before reaching the caves. After entering the caves, it’s a downward slope leading to the lake.

The tour experience includes a boat ride on the lake – the smaller lake leads into the much larger section, only accessible with cave diving. Along the tour, guides lecture about the history of the caves dating back to the mid-1800s.

Visitors can also choose a Wild Cave Tour experience, which lets you sleep overnight inside the caves.

The Lost Sea Adventure is part of the Civil War Trail Markers for its role in the war.

Address: 140 Lost Sea Rd, Sweetwater, TN 37874

Accomodation: Where to stay in Sweetwater

Website: www.thelostsea.com

18: Bell Witch Cave

Photo Courtesy: Wikimedia/Www78
  • Rate attraction:
  • 2
    0
  • View Map

Adams, Tennessee, isn’t the most popular travel destination in the state, but the legend of the Bell Witch continues to drive tourists to the Bell Witch Cave attraction. The cave is located nearby the Red River, near the former Bell Farm – the farm belonged to the Bell family, rumored to be haunted by the witch.

The Bell Witch Cave takes curious visitors through the eerie cave to see the site rumored to be where the witch retreated and dwelled. There are tales of encounters with the witch.

Visitors can take a guided tour of the cave, with the tour guide providing details about the myth while exploring the 500-ft long cave.

In addition to the cave, the tour experience can be extended to include the Bell Witch Cabin. The cabin is a replica which permits guests to walk through various rooms while hearing audio playback of the Bell Witch tale.

The Bell Witch Cave and Cabin are privately owned and only open for tours during the summer and October.

Address: 430 Keysburg Rd, Adams, TN 37010

Website: www.bellwitchcave.com

19: Ryman Auditorium

Photo Courtesy: Wikimedia/Daniel Schwen
  • Rate attraction:
  • 2
    0
  • View Map

With all the impressive architectural wonders in Nashville, one of the highlights is the Ryman Auditorium, a legendary country music venue. Ryman Auditorium is a National Historic Landmark that opened in 1892 to host some of the most iconic music artists in country music throughout history.

Ryman Auditorium first grew to prominence while being the home to the Grand Ole Opry – it’s sometimes referred to as the Grand Ole Opry House. It went on to become one of the major touring venues for country music acts performing in Nashville.

There were considerations for demolition due to extended periods of being inactive. Plans changed, and it was later restored while preserving several of the venue’s original features.

Today, the Ryman Auditorium includes seating for more than 2,300 people with a great design for high visibility from any seat. It’s an active performance venue where you can always find a show playing during your visit. It also hosts tours to learn about the history, admire the architecture, and explore the interior of the venue.

Address: 116 5th Ave N, Nashville, Tennessee 37219

Accomodation: Where to stay in Nashville

Website: www.ryman.com

Also Read: Nashville, Tennessee Top 10 Attractions

20: Crystal Shrine Grotto

Photo Courtesy: Wikimedia/Thomas R Machnitzki
  • Rate attraction:
  • 1
    0
  • View Map

The Memorial Park Cemetery in Memphis is a burial location of several notable people. The Crystal Shrine Grotto is the centerpiece of the cemetery, a project initiated in efforts to add decorations and more visual appeal to the site. The grotto was completed in 1955 and now listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

The Crystal Shrine Grotto is a man-made cave, built 60-ft deep in a hillside. It’s named after the quartz crystal used to make the cave. One of the most impressive features of the cave is the hand-built shrines. The shrines hold religious significance, depicting the journey of Christ on Earth.

The cemetery gardens and a pond surround the grotto. It’s open to the public – visitors can cross the pond bridge and get an up-close view at the detailed work of the grotto.

Address: 5668 Poplar Ave, Memphis, TN 38119

Accomodation: Where to stay in Memphis

Florida Top 20 Attractions

Florida is the perfect destination for those searching for sunshine, beaches, natural beauty, and culture. The Sunshine State is known for its beautiful weather that makes a trip to the beach perfect all year round.

Even if you don't want to go to the beach or visit a theme park, you can pick from a range of educational and entertaining attractions, such as visiting NASA centers, scuba diving, or even looking at forts that are centuries old.

Fishing, golfing, and hiking are just some of the outdoor adventures visitors to Florida enjoy. This list of the top 20 attractions in Florida can help you plan your perfect vacation.
